Text: [We see stunning views of wildlife and a hut in the middle of the forest. From the hut comes a strong man with a braided beard. A man has a child sitting in a shoulder bag. There is still snow around, but spring is already beginning to come into its reign. A man carries a child and speaks to her.]

Speaker: Rost
Text: What’s that now? Don’t like the cold? Can’t stay in today. We have a ritual to perform you and I. Here... wear this. It belonged to my daughter. Good. Today I speak your name, girl. But - will the Goddess speak it back? Normally it would be the mother who declares... if you had one. The whole village would attend, and Matriarchs perform the ritual. But... we are outcasts. Even so, we keep the tribe’s rituals. Otherwise we might become like the faithless Old Ones, who turned their backs on the Goddess. But their wickedness doomed them. To us were left the splendors of creation. Beasts of air, water, earth... and steel. It is one thing to hunt a beast, another to hunt a machine. You must be humble and respect their power. I will teach you this, one day…
[They climb a high mountain to a small shrine.]

Speaker: Rost
Text: High Matriarch Teersa? What is she doing here? Does she mean to forbid the ritual?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: No-no-no, off your knees! It’s nearly time. And yes, you may speak to me!

Speaker: Rost
Text: You came to bless the naming?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Have no six months gone by since we entrusted her to you?

Speaker: Rost
Text: But we are outcasts.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: You by choice, and she, well… I’m a High Matriarch, Rost. I bless whom I choose.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Then... you honor us.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Yes, yes. Now, go! And be ready to declare! Go! All-Mother, this child needs a name by which to know her, that your love may warm her life as the rising sun warms all the earth! Speak her name!

Speaker: Rost
Text: ALOY!!!

Speaker: Teersa
Text: And so her name are blessed!

Speaker: Lansra
Text: Stop this! At once! What have you done?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: I’ve blessed the naming of a child.

Speaker: Lansra
Text: Stubborn woman! You call that curse a child? What did she tell you about its birth, outcast? Answer!

Speaker: Rost
Text: I’ve done only what you asked -

Speaker: Lansra
Text: To raise it, yes. We said nothing of love.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Enough!

Speaker: Lansra
Text: And you... Blessing its name, like it was one of the Nora, one of the tribe!

Speaker: Rost
Text: I know my duty to them - and to you. I’m here. And wherever you go… I will follow.
[Rost is looking for Aloy, which is hiding in the bushes. She is watching a mother gathering blueberries along with several children.]

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy!

Speaker: Nora Mother
Text: Oooh, that’s a lot of berries. You are quite the gatherer, aren’t you, little Bast Now go and see if you can find some more. Well done, that’s a good boy.
[Aloy come to her holding a lot of blueberries.]

Speaker: Nora Mother
Text: Children, come with me. She’s an outcast, to be shunned. There… Oh, come on.
[Aloy runs away in a rage and does not notice the pit in which she falls. She explores it.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Rost! Down here! Rost! ROST! He won’t hear me. Some kind of cave?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Ew. Rats. Looks tight. But I can get through... This must be a ruin of the Metal World! One of the old places... Rost said never go in places like this… but I have to find a way out. There’s something up ahead... What’s that? A dead person! There’s something shiny there.
[She inspects the strange device.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Lights - everywhere! How does it do this? A metal door. Closed. Maybe this device I found can help? How do get it open? More lights... A shape. It’s connected to the door somehow.
[She turns the Holo Lock clockwise.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It changed color! The door changed color, too!
[The door is opened.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It did it! What’s that? It’s got a device, like the one I found.
[The device shows a hologram.]

Speaker: Unknown Man
Text: You think I want it this way? It’s the best I can do, he’s right behind you. Hi! Happy birthday Isaac! Daddy sure does love his little big man. Look, Daddy can’t be there with you and mom, but... We, can still have a party, right? Sure we can.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Show me... Show me again!

Speaker: Unknown Man
Text: I can do, he’s right behind you. Hi!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Hi.

Speaker: Unknown Man
Text: Happy birthday Isaac. Daddy sure does love his little big man. Look. Daddy can’t be there with you and mom, but… We can still have a party, right? Sure we can.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Happy Birthday, Isaac... Daddy sure does love his little big man.
[She goes further and squeezes through a gap.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why did they die here? What happened to them?
[Datapoint Log - Jackson Frye]

Speaker: Jackson Frye
Text: ...and pray for us sinners, now and at the hour of our debt, I mean, death. Sorry, it’s been a while and hoo, these meds Chana gave us are really something. So. Okay. From the top, kids. Hail Mary, full of grace...
[Datapoint Log - Ella Pontes]

Speaker: Ella Pontes
Text: And maybe that’s all need, you know? That moment the door opened and you were standing there, wearing that retro-weave dress, and the way you smiled... I had to look away or you were going to see. On my face. What had just... blossomed inside me, you know? Ha, it was just an instant, but I knew. I knew we’d be forever.
[Datapoint Log - Mia Sayied]

Speaker: Mia Sayied
Text: The earth shall soon dissolve like snow... the sun forbear to shine... but God, who called me here below... will be forever mine. And Machu Picchu. Always wanted to see that Never did. Why didn’t I go with Owen when he asked? Stupid. I should have gone. Well.
[Datapoint Log - Connor Chasson]

Speaker: Connor Chasson
Text: ...I mean, seriously, "record our thoughts for posterity"? Great idea, Director Evans. Like I haven’t done enough for posterity already? Like I wouldn’t be... here... like this... if not for posterity? I’m done with posterity. Posterity can go f...

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy! Aloy, are you down there! Aloy!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: He found me! Rost found me!

Speaker: Rost
Text: All-Mother be praised! Come, girl! Take my hand! You don’t belong down there! Come!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I fell in.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Such places are forbidden, Aloy. They are of the Metal World - What is that on your face?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Nothing. No.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Did you find it... down there? Give it to me.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: No!

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy, such things are dangerous!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: No!

Speaker: Rost
Text: Well if you’re young to go sneaking away from home you’re going to need to know how to survive in the wild. Come Aloy! Home now! But starting tomorrow you will learn to hunt.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: All these Shapes. What do they mean?

Speaker: Rost
Text: Take your bow.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Enough muttering to that plaything. We descend to the valley now. Follow.

Speaker: Rost
Text: The wilds can be dangerous, Aloy. You will need to stay close and do as I say.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I know.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Now, you’re still scratched up from that fall you took yesterday, so let’s start here. Take this medicine pouch, and I’ll show you how to fill it. See this plant, over here? It’s called Salvebrush. Come gather its berries in your pouch. Aloy, come now. Gather the berries. Now eat the berries.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Bleh.

Speaker: Rost
Text: They may taste bitter, but they can save your life. Always keep your pouch full of medicinal berries, flowers, and plants.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Where are we?

Speaker: Rost
Text: This valley is just a part of All-Mother’s Embrace.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Embrace?

Speaker: Rost
Text: The Nora tribe watches these lands, and keep rut the most dangerous machines – usually. Further downriver, we’ll find a herd of machines, and I will teach you how to hunt.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Are they dangerous?

Speaker: Rost
Text: All machines are dangerous, Alloy. Their power must be respected. But I will be beside you. Hmm. Aloy - a machine’s coming. Crouch, and follow me into the tall grass. There. Now stay low.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Little ones!

Speaker: Rost
Text: No, Aloy. Such machines are called Watchers. You must learn to avoid their gaze, if you are to survive in the wilds. I will show you. Listen close and do that I do. Stay still. Wait for it to pass. Now keep low and follow me across the trail to that Tall Grass. Ho. Another one. Let it pass. Come. Back this way. The slower you move, the quieter you’ll be. And crouched walking is quieter than upright. Wait for it. That’s the last of them. Let’s move on. You did well. They didn’t see or hear you. Now stay close. That herd should be just ahead.
[She see a boy climbing a mountain.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Who’s that?

Speaker: Rost
Text: Ignore him.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But why we up there? He’s smiling at us.

Speaker: Nora Brave Veteran
Text: Teeeeeeb! Get back where you belong! Teeeeeeb! Where are you?

Speaker: Rost
Text: Ignore him. We are outcasts, and he is of the tribe.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Maybe he doesn’t like the tribe.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Then he is a fool. Come now. Let’s find that herd. Follow. There. See them? These are called “Striders.”
[He screams loudly, scaring the herd.]

Speaker: Rost
Text: Hah! Git!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why’d you chase them off?

Speaker: Rost
Text: To show you how some machines startle easily if they detect you, and run away. They are best approached by stealth. Don’t worry. We’ll catch up with them further down the valley. You’ll see. Now I want you to find some rocks that fit the cup of your hand.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why?

Speaker: Rost
Text: Do as I say Aloy, and gather the rocks. I will show you how to use them. Those will do. Follow. Stop wasting time. There’s the herd. All right, it’s time to throw some rocks.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But rocks can’t hurt machines... right?

Speaker: Rost
Text: No, but they can distract them, draw them into traps… Like that Watcher over there. It must be dealt with, or it will warn the herd and send them running before we get in range.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Warn them? How?

Speaker: Rost
Text: The Machines speak to each other, Aloy - unless they are first silenced. Now you stay here on the ridge. On my signal, throw rocks and draw the Watcher over to me. Wait for my signal. Aloy, throw a rock near me! There. Come, girl, it’s safe now. Harvest the kill, so I can teach you how to make arrows. Good. Now gather stalks of Ridge-Wood from the plants over there. Good. Now I see you’ve already gathered stalks of Ridge-Wood. Use the stalk, as arrow shafts, and Metal Shards for arrow heads. Good. You’ll never run out of arrows, if you know how to craft what you need. Let’s put those arrows to use. Follow. Here, stay low in the grass -- and be quiet! It is time to make your first kill, Aloy. A Strider. One of the weaker Machines. But even a weak Machine can kill a hunter -- if she is careless. You must study your prey. Its hide is thick, but there are spots where it is-vulnerable -- like its eye. Can you guess another?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The canister on its back -- is that a weakness?

Speaker: Rost
Text: Yes. How did you guess that?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The device, it showed me!

Speaker: Rost
Text: That plaything? Stop playing games. Now take down that Strider. Target the eye, or the canister. And if it charges, be ready to roll out of the way.
[She shoots the Strider.]

Speaker: Rost
Text: Keep firing! You did well today, but you have much to learn. Tomorrow we train again.
[They hear a scream.]

Speaker: Rost
Text: What was that?!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That boy! The one running the brave trails!

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy – quick!
[They run to the sound of screams and moans. When they arrive, they see that the fallen boy is surrounded by a herd of Watchers.]

Speaker: Rost
Text: I can do nothing. It’s only a matter of time before the machines find that boy and kick him to death. But if I shoot, it will cause a stampede and it will trample him.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But I can see the paths they take!

Speaker: Rost
Text: Stop telling stories.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m not! I can sneak through.

Speaker: Rost
Text: You will not.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy!
[She breaks free from his hands and runs to the boy.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I need to move slowly and quietly, so I can sneak past them. Can’t let them see me… Got to be careful… I need to see their paths… Almost there… There he is...
[She talks to him.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Hey!

Speaker: Teb
Text: What?! Huh – How?!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Shhh! Follow me!
[She leads him through the grazing herd.]

Speaker: Teb
Text: How do you know to avoid them? How are you doing this? How is this possible?
[She comes to Rost.]

Speaker: Rost
Text: So... it is no plaything.

Speaker: Teb
Text: Wait... All-Mother bless that girl. Bless you both.

Speaker: Nora Brave Veteran
Text: Boy!

Speaker: Teb
Text: She... she saved me.

Speaker: Teb
Text: I... I just wanted...

Speaker: Nora Brave Veteran
Text: Boy. Seal your lips. They are outcasts, both. And she... she is motherless. Come now. Back to Mother’s Heart. And you…
[He hits Teb in the head and they leaves.]

Speaker: Rost
Text: That boy should not have spoken to us, it’s against tribal law. We’ll go home now. Follow.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I know the way.
[Later...]
[Someone throws a stone at Aloy, right in the head.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Ahh!

Speaker: Bast
Text: Stay away. No-Mother!
[He throws another stone, but Aloy catches it. She decided to knock the rock from Bast’s hand.]

Speaker: Bast
Text: Ahh!

Speaker: Nora Woman
Text: Children, away from there! Back to picking berries!

Speaker: Rost
Text: You’re bleeding, let me have a look.  Here, hold still, I’ll get it.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why?

Speaker: Rost
Text: Shhhh.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why am I an outcast?

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy... this is not the time.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Who was my mother?

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy... I’ve told you before, that is not for us to know. You were just a newborn when the Matriarchs brought you to me.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So the Matriarchs, they know?

Speaker: Rost
Text: It’s not so simple.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But they know?

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy, we are outcasts.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So how do I make them tell me?

Speaker: Rost
Text: The Matriarchs? There is a way, perhaps -

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So, tell me.

Speaker: Rost
Text: It will be dangerous.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: How!?

Speaker: Rost
Text: It would take years of training.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I don’t care. How do I do it? Tell me!

Speaker: Rost
Text: The Proving, the tribe’s rite of passage, held every year. Those who pass become braves, but to the one who wins - The Matriarchs grant a boon.

Speaker: Alby
Text: A boon?

Speaker: Rost
Text: Yes,Whatever the winner wants.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Then I’ll do it. Whatever it takes. I’ll win the Proving.

Speaker: Rost
Text: I see, we best get started then.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Your training will be hard, and it will take years.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Start training? Yes, follow.
[Years passing. Aloy trains hard and persistently, gradually improving her archery skills, climbing rocks and balancing. And so, in one of the winters...]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Rost… Rost!... Rooost!!! Where is he? Two days before the Proving, and he goes off without me? He wouldn’t do that.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’ll do what I have to. Where’s he go to?
[She notices him standing on a rock.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: He’s just... standing there. What’s going on with him?

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy. You’re here.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Did you want to be alone?

Speaker: Rost
Text: No. We must speak. I’ve been thinking about your training, Aloy. You’ve learned to hunt, learned to survive. But I fear there’s a lesson I failed to teach you. Would you learn it now?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Of course. I’ll always learn what you have to teach.

Speaker: Rost
Text: There has been some... trouble, recently. It affords an opportunity to learn this lesson, but it will be dangerous. You must come prepared… or you wall die. Descend into the Embrace and hunt until you have gathered the Parts for Fire Arrows.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Fire Arrows? What kind of trouble are we talking about?

Speaker: Rost
Text: Once you have the Parts, you will meet me there, at the gate beyond the Village of Mother’s Heart.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The North Gate? At the edge of the Embrace?

Speaker: Rost
Text: Yes. Now be on your way.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Is something else bothering you?

Speaker: Rost
Text: No. I am fine.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Are you worrying about what happens... after the Proving?

Speaker: Rost
Text: What happens is clear. You will be accepted as one of the tribe, and I will still be an outcast, to be shunned.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Rost, even if the tribe accepts me, I won’t -

Speaker: Rost
Text: There is much to do, Aloy. We will discuss this later.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: ...Okay. I’ll go gather the parts. But I’m also going to pay Karst a visit.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy, that man breaks the law every time he speaks to you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And I’m glad he does. I want to buy a Tripcaster, and no other trader will sell to outcasts.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Stock it with ammunition, then. You’ll find use for that weapon tonight.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That sounds ominous. All right, see you at the North Gate.
[Aloy gathering the parts.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Somethings really bothering him. If he thinks I’m gonna abandon him, he’s wrong.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The Embrace. My whole life, I’ve never gone beyond this valley. That’ll change after the Proving. Two days. Two days until I get answers. Two days, and I’ll know who she was. And why I was cast out at birth. As if there could be an excuse for that. All right, time to gather the Parts for some Fire Arrows. I should find a herd.
[Aloy collects all the necessary parts and crafts the Fire Arrows. Then she goes to a settlement called Mother’s Cradle.]

Speaker: Greeting Nora Brave
Text: I can’t hear anything! No, not a thing!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Lucky they don’t talk to me. Don’t think I’d be very nice.

Speaker: Greeting Nora Child
Text: I CAN’T HEAR ANYTHING!

Speaker: Greeting Nora Brave
Text: Goddess! Why won’t she leave me alone?

Speaker: Greeting Young Nora Hunter
Text: I just want to go about my day.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Time to see Karst and get a Tripcaster. No one else around. Looks safe to meet. My guess is, he’ll be waiting for me. There he is. Looks nervous.

Speaker: Karst
Text: Well, well, well, an outcast on my doorstep. All-Mother protect me.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Surprised you saw me, the way you keep looking every other direction to make sure no one’s watching. Careful there, or you’ll sprain your neck.

Speaker: Karst
Text: It’s always a pain in the neck when you show up, girl, one way or another.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Humph. Last time I visited, you had a Tripcaster available for trade. Still got it?

Speaker: Karst
Text: I do. But you’d need to bring me a Scrapper Lens. What can I say? Special weapons don’t come cheap.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Oh. I can pay. Took down a Scrapper not long ago, stripped out the lens in perfect condition.

Speaker: Karst
Text: I’ll be the judge of that. Show me.
[She trade with Karst.]

Speaker: Karst
Text: Now that you’ve got a Tripcaster, practice how to use it in someplace else, all right? My life’s exciting enough without a bunch of Shock Wire booby traps to trip over.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Really? Could have fooled me.

Speaker: Karst
Text: - snort -

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Will you be around later, in case I want to make another trade?

Speaker: Karst
Text: I’ll be here. Same as usual, bring me the parts you harvest from any machines you hunt. The better the parts, the more Shards I’ll pay. Be sure to take a close look at my inventory, though. Who knows, maybe I’ve got something that could give you an edge in the Proving.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Is there a reason why you re acting so cranky today?

Speaker: Karst
Text: Once you run the Proving and get made a brave, you’ll deal with traders in Mother’s Heart. Maybe I don’t like losing customers.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Traders who don’t break the law and deal with outcasts, you mean?

Speaker: Karst
Text: That’s right. Our days of crime will be behind us... so long as you keep quiet.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Are you worried I’m going to tell someone that you trade with outcasts?

Speaker: Karst
Text: I don’t think you’re the kind who talks. But you never know.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You can stop worrying. The secrets safe with me.

Speaker: Karst
Text: That’s what I figured. But I don’t mind hearing it.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why do you take the risk, trading with outcasts?

Speaker: Karst
Text: Every time, you ask. If a big, meaningful talk is what you’re after, move along.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It’s because you used to be one, isn’t it?

Speaker: Karst
Text: Yeah. Got caught poking around one of the Metal Ruins out beyond the Embrace. Matriarchs said I was tainted and gave me five years.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What did you see in the Ruins?

Speaker: Karst
Text: Nothing I could make sense of. After my shunning I tried living back in Mother’s Heart but… everyone I knew had moved on, and there were so many people, everywhere I turned. I like it better out here.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The only person I’ve ever told about our trades is Rost.

Speaker: Karst
Text: Yeah, well, not like he can turn me in, even if he wanted to. Law and duty sort of a man, that Rost. I don’t know how you stand it.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You really don’t know why he was cast out?

Speaker: Karst
Text: I’ve told you, no. I don’t think anyone knows what he did. But it must’ve been serious, because his term is for life.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I guess that concludes our business.

Speaker: Karst
Text: All right Good luck in the Proving. Blessing of All-Mother and all that.
[Aloy walks away.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’ve got what I need. Time to meet Rost at the North Gate.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Whatever they’re hunting out there, it doesn’t sound easy.
[Aloy returns to Rost.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: There he is, right where he said he’d be. Always is.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy. You’re here. You have the Fire Arrows?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I do. Those explosions and shouts beyond the Embrace - is that the trouble you were talking about?

Speaker: Rost
Text: You will know soon enough. Until then, we wait for dark.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Wait for dark? Look, Rost, I’ve thought it through and I’m not going to shun you after the Proving, okay? I’m just... I won’t do it. I’m not about to pretend that you never raised me.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy... the law forbids all contact.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It does, and I don’t care. I know what duty means for you, Rost, but all tribal law has ever done for me is take things away. And that’s not going to happen again.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy... I must obey the law.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And so you will. I knew you’d say that, so... this is what we’ll do. I will come to you in secret. No one will see me, so I won’t get in trouble. And I know you won’t talk to me because... it’s against the law. But I’ll talk to you. It’ll be my crime, not yours. You’ll just... listen. And that’s how we’ll handle this.

Speaker: Rost
Text: ...You’ve... put a lot of thought to this.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I know, right? So you can stop worrying. It’s handled.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Yes. So it is.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I don’t understand. Those explosions are outside the Embrace. What can we do from in here?

Speaker: Rost
Text: The lesson will be taught in due time, Aloy. Until then, we wait.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I saw Karst and got that Tripcaster I was talking about.

Speaker: Rost
Text: I hate to think what that outlaw trader charged for a weapon of that make.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It wasn’t cheap, but the Tripcaster is worth it.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Perhaps. You’ll know its worth soon enough.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Still a while to go before dark. I guess I’ll get some rest.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Good idea. There will be no time for sleep tonight.
[Aloy is resting by the fire before nightfall. Then she go to the North Gate. Rost whistles and the gate opens.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Opening a gate for an outcast?

Speaker: Rost
Text: Some who are shunned reaped honor before disgrace.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So much for tribal law.

Speaker: Rost
Text: I spoke to no one. And now we must both keep silent for we are outside the Embrace. These are the true wilds, Aloy, with threats unlike any you have ever faced.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That carcass! What sort of beast was that?

Speaker: Rost
Text: The tribe calls it a Sawtooth -- and it is something new. Something angry. Since they first started appearing ten years ago, they have killed many braves.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Yeah.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Follow the path. It’s not far.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That cabin. What happened to it?

Speaker: Rost
Text: A machine. That’s what.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What sort of machine does that?

Speaker: Rost
Text: The sort of machine you’re hunting how.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Oh... I see. A Watcher carcass. I’ll harvest the Parts.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Watch your surroundings. It won’t be much further now.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why are we the only ones out here tonight? Why can’t the tribe’s braves hunt this machine?

Speaker: Rost
Text: They did. The kills we’ve passed are theirs. And tomorrow they will hunt again.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: They won’t need to. This machine will be my kill.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Or your death, if you’re not careful.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: An entire lodge, wrecked?! By Sawtooths? How many were there?

Speaker: Rost
Text: I didn’t bring you here to answer questions. Aloy. I brought you here to deal with that.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It’s huge. How do you defeat it?

Speaker: Rost
Text: That will be for you to decide. This hunt is yours to make, Aloy - yours alone. No matter what happens, I will not intervene. Do you understand? You are on your own.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I should stay out of sight. I can use the tall grass to approach… Let’s see... where can I place my traps? That wasn’t a warning. It saw me! I should scan it, see what that reveals.
[Aloy defeats Sawtooth.]

Speaker: Rost
Text: Why did I bring you here?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Not to answer questions.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy...

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Survival requires perfection. It was a test, to hone my skills against a dangerous new machine.

Speaker: Rost
Text: No. Follow. These are Nora hunting lands. They must be protected.

Speaker: Rost
Text: If you hadn’t destroyed the Sawtooth, how many Brave might it have killed or injured tomorrow? The lesson lives within the question, Aloy. For years you’ve trained to win the Proving only for yourself. As a brave, it will be yo duty to fight for your tribe -

Speaker: Aloy
Text: My tribe?! You said I wouldn’t need them.

Speaker: Rost
Text: But I never said the tribe wouldn’t need you! The strength to stand alone, Aloy, is the strength to make a stand. To serve a purpose greater than yourself. That is the lesson you must learn. And remember it… after the Proving, and after I am gone.

Speaker: Rost
Text: We are finished here. Follow.
[Next scene.]

Speaker: Rost
Text: Dawn has passed. This will be your last day in the Embrace as an outcast. Use the time to set your mind on the challenges before you. When it is time for you to go to Mother’s Heart, I will be waiting for you along the way.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I understand the final lesson. Rost.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Do you?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But if I’m going to stand for something, it’ll have to be something I believe in.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Then I hope you find it, Aloy. I hope you do.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’ll see you at Mo h rs Heart, then.

Speaker: Rost
Text: You will.
[Aloy finishes all her activities in the region and get back to Rost near Mother’s Heart settlement.]

Speaker: Rost
Text: So. It’s time. Are you ready?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Yes. I guess. It’s... louder than I expected.

Speaker: Rost
Text: You’ve never been so close before.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I guess everything’s bigger up close.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Soon it’ll all seem familiar. Like home.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I don’t know about that.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Look for High Matriarch Teersa. She will help you. Any other concerns?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What should I expect once I’m inside?

Speaker: Rost
Text: There will be people celebrating, and feasting. More than you’ve ever seen in one place. No other village compares to Mother’s Heart. It is the seat of the High Matriarchs, a center of Nora life, a jewel of the Sacred Land. Give it time, and you will grow fond of it... as I was, back when I was of the tribe.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Are you sure they’re going to let me in?

Speaker: Rost
Text: I’ve told you. Aloy. By law, any child outcast can run in the Proving --

Speaker: Aloy
Text: "And any who pass are made braves, and are outcasts no more." I know that. But not everyone follows the law like you do, Rost.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Have faith, Aloy. The tribe will honor your right.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Any final lessons before I head in?

Speaker: Rost
Text: No, you’ve learned every lesson the wilds have to teach.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It was you who taught me, not the wilds. Not sure my bow and spear will be much help in there, though.

Speaker: Rost
Text: It is with bow and spear that you’ll win hat you’ve what you’ve wanted all these years. Aloy. Answers.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m ready to do this. See you back home in a few days?

Speaker: Rost
Text: You will not find me there, Aloy. Here. Take this, to... remember.
[He gave her a pendant.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why are you talking like we’ll never see each other again? No… No…

Speaker: Rost
Text: You should be with the tribe. And I will always be an outcast.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But I told you, I have that figured out! I’ll come to you in secret. I’ll be the one breaking the law, not you! You don’t even have to talk to me!

Speaker: Rost
Text: This... attachment to me will only hold you back. It IS my wish that you embrace the tribe. You’ve lived in isolation long enough.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Not until now, I didn’t.

Speaker: Rost
Text: For your sake. I must go where you will never find me. This is goodbye.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: No. It’s not. You taught me how to track. Wherever you go, I can follow.

Speaker: Rost
Text: Not this time.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: This time… and every time. I’ll be wearing this when I find you.

Speaker: Rost
Text: May All-Mother bless you, Aloy.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And you.
[She goes to the Gate.]

Speaker: Nora Gate Guard
Text: You will turn back, outcast. Or bleed - your choice.
[The gates suddenly opens.]

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Make way! Make way! Braves, stand aside, she is welcome here. Mother’s Heart is open to you, child. Come. I assure you, most Nora aren’t as rude as those idiots.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You’re... Teersa?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Who else would I be? Come on now… I’ve been waiting for this day a long time.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You have?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Oh yes. But for the moment. I must leave you. I have other outsiders to keep safe tonight!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You... what?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Envoys from another tribe - the Carja - come to observe the Proving. And oh how the Nora hate the Carja!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Carja?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: But that’s my problem. We will talk later. In the meantime, enjoy die festival. Oh! Down the path to the right, you’ll find an old friend who can’t wait to see you!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But I don’t know anyone here!

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Ha! Try telling his that. We will talk later! May the Goddess protect!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: ...What is going on…?
[She walks down the path and sees Teb.]

Speaker: Teb
Text: It is Aloy, isn’t it? I’m remembering your name correctly?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Are you the "old friend" Teersa told me about? I don’t know you.

Speaker: Teb
Text: I see you don’t recognize me. Well, it was a long time ago. Teb is my name. You were half my size when you saved me from a herd of Machines.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I remember. You tried to thank me.

Speaker: Teb
Text: I never forgot that day. All these years I hoped to see you again - if you came to run in the Proving. As you can see, I didn’t turn out to be much of a hunter. I serve the tribe as a Stitcher instead. A maker of garments and armor. In preparation for this day, I’ve made an outfit for you. I hope you’ll like it.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What’s it going to cost?

Speaker: Teb
Text: Cost? Nothing! Consider it the thanks I tried to give years ago, long overdue.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Thank you, Teb. I’ve never had anything like this before.

Speaker: Teb
Text: Well, it’s yours. I think you’ll find it affords more protection than... what you were wearing. Every outfit offers some advantage. It’s always a trade-off. Anyway, I shouldn’t keep you any longer. Head for the Matriarchs’ Lodge if you want to find Teersa. You’ll know it when you see it. A large wooden building with an angry mob waiting outside.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Teersa said something about envoys from another tribe?

Speaker: Teb
Text: Yes, that’s what the mobs angry about. Carja, visiting our Sacred Land for the first time in years. I’d expect to see some tomatoes fly, maybe rocks. Hopefully not spears. In any case, be ready to duck.

Speaker: Karst
Text: Aloy! Over here!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Karst? What are you doing here?

Speaker: Karst
Text: Careful. Pretend like we’ve never met I wasn’t supposed to trade with outcasts in the wilds, remember?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: How could I forget. And how generous of you to talk to me now.

Speaker: Karst
Text: Don’t be like that. You know I’ll be rooting for you in the Proving tomorrow. Can’t wait to see the looks on some of these faces when you win. And if you need any last minute supplies, I’m your man.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So... Mother’s Heart thought you preferred the wilds.

Speaker: Karst
Text: Well, a man can’t drink alone all the time, can he? Truth is, I get lonely once in awhile. There. I admitted it. Don’t think less of me.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I won’t hold it against you... if you give me a discount.

Speaker: Karst
Text: You can’t be...

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m joking, Karst. It’s good to see you.

Speaker: Karst
Text: Hmph. Don’t go soft on me. All sales are final. If it breaks, you’re out of luck.

Speaker: Karst
Text: All right. Let’s do this.
[She trade with Karst and and goes further.]

Speaker: Jezza
Text: In a moment we shall bless the Proving. But first we have guests to welcome.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: For two years we have been at peace with the Carja! It is time to restore our bonds of trade with Meridian. These envoys com to us under a banner of peace!

Speaker: Sun Priest
Text: An annunciation of gratitude. Written by the hand of Sun-King Avad...

Speaker: Lut
Text: Killers and slavers! Killers and slavers!

Speaker: Nora Brave
Text: Yeah! Faceless wretch!

Speaker: Erend
Text: Hey hey hold your fruit! Nora faithful - hold your fruit! I’m Oseram, not Carja, so I’ll put it to you straight: the 13th Sun King was murderous bing! He was! A tyrant and a monster! Raided my tribe for blood sacrifice, just like yours! My own sister was taken! I hated he Carja! But the 13th King is dead two years now, and who killed him? The 14th! Not because he lusted for power, but because someone had to put an end to his father’s atrocities! The message this poor priest means to read is an apology. Straight from the lips of the 14th king. So please, can’t you lend him your ears?

Speaker: Sun Priest
Text: Thank you. An annunciation of gratitude... written by the hand of Sun-King Avad... 14th Luminance of the Radiant Line…

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Looks like it’s on that... bald man. One of the visitors? “Unknown device detected?” What’s that mean? He’s wearing a Focus -- just like mine!
[She talks to the man.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You’re the only other person I’ve ever seen wearing a Focus. Where did you get yours?

Speaker: Olin
Text: What?! A Nora -- wearing one of these?! That’s impossible! Your tribe fears the old places, forbids them!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Who says I’m like other Nora?

Speaker: Olin
Text: Why... I guess you’re not, if you’ve gone delving in the ruins of the Metal World… Ahhh...!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What’s wrong?

Speaker: Olin
Text: Apologies... a malfunction.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Olin! You making friends with locals, are we?

Speaker: Olin
Text: I’ll... I’ll come back.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Wait.

Speaker: Olin
Text: No, uh -- we’ll talk later. Have to go...

Speaker: Erend
Text: Whoa. I guess he’s more hung over than I thought. Hey, you’ve got the same trinket that Olin has on his head. Since when did those become fashionable?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: His name is Olin? Who is he? And where did he get one of these?

Speaker: Erend
Text: He’s just a scrounger with friends in high places. He spends half his time digging for artifacts, the other half drinking or dicing. As for the trinket, I guess he dug it up somewhere. Just a weird old jewel he sticks on his face. No offense. Looks great on you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I thought your friend was going to go down in a hail of fruit, but you really calmed the crowd.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Thanks. I wasn’t sure I could do it. The Nora are still pissed with the Carja about the Red Raids, and who can blame them?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I want to ask you something else.

Speaker: Erend
Text: If you want. But I’ll also be around after that Blessing thing, if that’d be a better time to talk.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: If the Carja have such a cruel history, how did you end up serving them?

Speaker: Erend
Text: The last king and his men were butchers. But the new king wants peace. There’s nothing cruel about that. Besides, the Carja don’t just fight. They build. Take Meridian. Next to it, everything else is just a bunch of sticks and stones.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Just how big is Meridian? What’s it like?

Speaker: Erend
Text: Where do I even start? My tribesmen are masters of the forge, the best tinkers in the world, but when it comes to building… roads, and buildings tall as mountains. The Carja have us beat. The city soars over a canyon, with more bridges than the Nora have. And across the valley stands the Spire, like a blade thrust into the sky, reﬂecting the sun. You really owe it to yourself to see it. So consider that a challenge. Or an invitation.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I never heard anything about "Red Raids" growing up. What were those?

Speaker: Erend
Text: Your tribe was at war, and you didn’t even know? Were you kept hidden away? Did you have overprotective parents or something?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I grew up as an outcast, shunned by the tribe.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Oh. Yeah, I’ve heard the Nora do that. Seems cruel if you ask me. But even an outcast knows about The Derangement of the Machines, right? How they get deadlier every year? Well, the Mad Sun-King figured if he spilled enough blood to the Sun God, it would calm the Machines. Didn’t work. But for years he raided the tribes and took captives for sacrifice, my sister among them. The Nora put up a good fight, but... lives were lost.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Your sister was taken captive and sacrificed? That’s terrible.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Ha! Captive, yes, sacrificed, no. Takes more than a few Carja to finish Ersa. She got away, and now she’s my captain - Captain of the entire Vanguard, favored by the Sun-King himself.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: How did she survive?

Speaker: Erend
Text: Oh, it’s a story all right, but it takes a while to tell. Maybe another time, over a drink or three? Or just come to Meridian and meet her yourself. I think you’d like each other. You’re both rather, ah… direct.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So what happened? How did it all end?

Speaker: Erend
Text: The Mad King’s own son united Carja rebels with Oseram Freebooters. Together we did the impossible: took back Meridian and killed the crazy old king. So now the son sits on the throne, and it’s a big improvement Under Avad, there’s no more sacrifices, no more slavery. People from all tribes are welcome in Meridian now, even Nora exiles. You really should come visit.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Who are the Oseram?

Speaker: Erend
Text: That’s my tribe, far to the northwest. We’re good at three things: Arguing, working steel, and brewing.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And "Freebooters?" What are those?

Speaker: Erend
Text: I guess you could say we were mercenaries - warriors for pay. Except a lot more loyal than that makes us sound. Avad couldn’t have taken down his father without our metal and muscle. And now some of us serve proudly as his personal Vanguard.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You said the machines have been getting more dangerous every year?

Speaker: Erend
Text: Yeah. I don’t have to tell you that, right?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: First I’ve heard of it.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Oh. Sorry. I just... assumed everyone knew. The way I hear it, fifteen, twenty years ago, the machines weren’t always pissed off like they are now. When a hunter came at them, they’d spook and run. So it was hard to take them down, but not dangerous -- so long as you were smart enough to jump out of the way. But then The Derangement starts up, and everything changes. Now, when a hunter fires a shot, the machines snarl and charge right at him major risk, A few more years pass, and they start attacking people on sight. Going anywhere becomes a And if that wasn’t bad enough, entirely new kinds of machines start showing up. Bigger, meaner -- and heavily armed.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Like the Sawtooth?

Speaker: Erend
Text: Yeah, ten years ago, that one. But every couple years or so, something worse comes along. Believe me.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So what’s making it happen?

Speaker: Erend
Text: No one knows. And the machines, they aren’t telling.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I want to ask about something you said before.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Ask away.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What else do you know about Olin?

Speaker: Erend
Text: Is he really that interesting? I’m starting to get jealous. Well, he scours the wilds for ruins, digs up stuff, and sells it to nobles. When he’s not scrounging, he’s scouting. Exactly the skills you want the man guiding your expedition to have. I’ve known him a few years. He’s a loyal companion, cares for his family, holds his drink well enough. I like him. But besides that, not much to tell.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’ve never seen armor like yours before.

Speaker: Erend
Text: You’ve never seen Vanguard steel? Well, let me introduce you. Ring locked. Impact protected. Sturdy enough to choke a Sawtooth. Has to be. The Vanguard are the Sun-King’s best, life-takers and Machine-breakers to a one. Might even give a Nora Warmaid like you more trouble than she can handle.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: With all that metal to slow you down? I doubt it.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Yeah, hard to say. From where I’m standing, looks like a pretty even match.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I should make my way to the Blessing.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Yeah. Look, maybe I shouldn’t say this, but it’s obvious that you don’t belong in this... backwater. I mean, you’re smart, you’re obviously capable, and well, I mean, look at you...

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What are you talking about?

Speaker: Erend
Text: You know what. If you ever visit Meridian, look me up. I’ll show you around, make introductions. It’d be a whole new life, if you want it. Anyway, I have to go to that Blessing thing, too. So... see you around, maybe?
[Aloy goes to the Blessing.]

Speaker: Lansra
Text: We’ll start the blessing when all aspirants are in place.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Aloy. Take your place right there. The prayer lantern is yours I made it for you.

Speaker: Lansra
Text: Pheh. Blasphemy.

Speaker: Jezza
Text: Sisters… Aspirants, before each of you sits a prayer lantern crafted by your mother. In her honor, light its flame!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: In honor of Rost, and all he did to help me get here.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: All-Mother, hear our prayer. What is the child, but a Mother’s hope that takes ﬂight? A glowing flame that climbs the air set free to the wind. Sailing the sky ’ til it fades and falls? So from one to another passes the chain of love.
[After the ceremony.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: There’s Olin. I haves me questions for him. Hello, Olin.

Speaker: Olin
Text: You know my name? ...Ah. Guess Erend told you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why did you act so strange when we spoke earlier?

Speaker: Olin
Text: Must be this festival. I’m really not one for crowds. Maybe I should just turn in --

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Stop dodging my questions.

Speaker: Olin
Text: All right, cool your fire. I got nothing to hide.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What are you doing here, Olin? Why come to Nora land?

Speaker: Olin
Text: Erend needed a scout for his expedition, and a second for his drinking, that’s all. Someone to stop the Sun-Priest getting lost. When all this is over, I’m back to delving ruins. Rummaging for scrap, scrounging up trinkets to sell.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So you’re an explorer?

Speaker: Olin
Text: Just another outlander, girl. A man’s got to make his Shards. I just make mine in service to the king’s court, that’s all.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’ve never seen anyone else with a Focus. Where exactly did you find it?

Speaker: Olin
Text: In the ruin north of “The Claim” – that’s our name for Oseram homeland. Up there, the metal seams run deep. Steel giants half-buried in loose soil, forgotten caves that the Old Ones bored into mountain rock... Your eyes just lit up.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I found my Focus in a cave just like you’re describing. A ruin of the Old Ones.

Speaker: Olin
Text: If you’ve delved yourself, you know as much as I do. Go to those places for answers, not me.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: When we spoke earlier, you winced, then looked like you were in pain -- or frightened. Did your Focus show you something?

Speaker: Olin
Text: It didn’t show me anything. I told you, it malfunctioned. Happens all the time.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You’re not a very convincing liar.

Speaker: Olin
Text: Do you always accuse people you’ve just met of lying?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Only the ones who aren’t telling the truth.

Speaker: Olin
Text: Fire and spit, girl. I’m a plain-hammered man with nothing to hide. You don’t believe me, that’s your trouble, not mine.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I don’t understand. We have this... device in common, but you can’t wait to stop talking to me.

Speaker: Olin
Text: I already have all the friends I need, girl. I don’t need the bother.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m used to being shunned by the tribe. I thought you’d be different.

Speaker: Olin
Text: It’s nothing personal. It really isn’t. You should... try to enjoy yourself tonight. Big day tomorrow. Always best to make every day count.
[At the door.]

Speaker: Resh
Text: Motherless chuff.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What’d you say?

Speaker: Resh
Text: Find your bed, outcast, and dream of winning the Proving. That’s the closest you’re going to get.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Oh, this is the bed-house? With you standing guard, I figured it was the latrine.

Speaker: Resh
Text: Your - your very presence here mocks –
[Aloy shuts the door.]

Speaker: Bast
Text: Well, well - look who’s come in from the wild! The motherless outcast! I see you’ve still got a scar from where that rock I threw hit you! Now that’s a cherished memory.

Speaker: Vala
Text: You can be a real lard sometimes, Bast. Cut it out.

Speaker: Bast
Text: You didn’t know the words to the Blessing, did you? But no one hears your prayers anyway.
[Aloy talks to him.]

Speaker: Bast
Text: Aw, you even try to dress like real Nora. Not that it fools anyone.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So this is how it’s going to be with you, is it?

Speaker: Bast
Text: This is how it’s going to be with everyone, outcast. You belong in the wilds, not Mother’s Heart And you definitely don’t belong in the Proving.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You can sense it. You already know you’re going to lose.

Speaker: Bast
Text: Ha! I’ve trained all my life for the Proving! I’m not afraid of you-- I’m not afraid of anything!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Really? Confidence is quiet. You’re not.

Speaker: Bast
Text: You know, I often think of the day I gave you that scar. It’s a cherished memory.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The look on your face when I knocked that stone out of your hand was pretty entertaining. But I suppose you leave that part of the story out when you tell it, don’t you?

Speaker: Bast
Text: I branded you that day to mark your shame.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: All you did that day was make me stronger. Just wait. I’ll show you tomorrow.

Speaker: Bast
Text: Yeah, right! This is boring! Time for Bast to get some sleep! You’ll be the one surprised tomorrow, outcast. Not me.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Oh, are you going to shut your mouth? Because that would be a surprise.
[Next she talks to Vala.]

Speaker: Vala
Text: Nice job handling Bast. That should keep him quiet. ’Til morning, anyway.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I don’t believe we’ve met. I’m Aloy.

Speaker: Vala
Text: Oh, I know who you are. The competition. The others, they’ll finish the Proving, most of them. But win it? That’s down to Bast, you... or me. Vala.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Nice to meet you, Vala. You’re right. I am going to win tomorrow.

Speaker: Vala
Text: Never celebrate a victory before its earned, girl. My mother taught me that. Now if you’ll excuse me, I’m going to get some sleep. I plan to be well-rested when I run you into the ground tomorrow. Your bunk’s right there when you want it.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Okay. Thanks.
[Aloy goes to sleep.]

Speaker: Vala
Text: So. Your first day in Mother’s Heart. What d’you think? You’ve never slept in a Nora lodge before. Not very private.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Comforts and distractions. That’s what I think.

Speaker: Vala
Text: Not all comforts are bad.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Comforts are weakness.

Speaker: Vala
Text: You sound just like my mother. You can always go back to living in the wilds if you have to. In the meantime, get some rest.
[On the next day.]

Speaker: Resh
Text: Braves -- ready yourselves!  What will it take to get you out of here?
[The Proving starts. First they need to kill a Grazer (some kind of deer) and pick up one of its horns. She succeeds but Bash knocks the horn out of her hands with an arrow shot.]

Speaker: Resh
Text: Your trophy is shattered outcast! Looks like you’ll need another.
[She gets another horn and runs to catch up with the rest. To win, she needs to get to a certain place among the first.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’ve got to catch up! Faster! Come on!

Speaker: Proctor
Text: Slow and steady now. All you need is to finish. That makes all but one. Is the outcast coming?

Speaker: Contestant
Text: She was behind me!

Speaker: Proctor
Text: Looks strong, thought. Dead last, girl. Might as well walk from here. Bast will win. Or Vala. But you’ll be made a brave, so long as you finish.
[Aloy decides her options.]

Speaker: Proctor
Text: Ho now! - that’s an old trail. Two died on it last year. It’s falling apart! Better dead last than dead altogether!  By All-Mother! Are you crazy?! You’re going to kill yourself!  It doesn’t get any easier! You’re insane to go that way!
Action: (Aloy readies for the jump) (she makes it)

Speaker: Aloy
Text: No way but forward now.

Speaker: Contestant
Text: Who’s in the lead? I can’t see!

Speaker: Contestant
Text: Bast, with Vala right behind!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Come on now! Faster! Stop dragging! Got to keep going!

Speaker: Contestant
Text: Hey - out there! The outcast!

Speaker: Contestant
Text: On the Old Trail? Is she crazy?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Good. I’m gaining!

Speaker: Contestant
Text: Look! The outcast is catching up!

Speaker: Contestant
Text: How’d she get up there?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Made it. Come on now. Hurry. Keep at it... I’ve trained my whole life for this. They had a tribe... but I had the wilds… Precision... not enough... must be… perfect. Come on, come tins, you can make it… Can’t let them beat me now!
[She outrun Bast and Vala for just a second.]

Speaker: Bast
Text: She didn’t win! The outcast cheated!

Speaker: Proctor
Text: An outcast? Win the Proving? Never!
[Aloy holds her breath...]

Speaker: Proctor
Text: For she is a brave now!

Speaker: Vala
Text: You did it.

Speaker: Proctor
Text: As are you all - so long as you put your trophy on the altar. But it is Aloy, once outcast, an now brave, who is sit among you!
[Her heart pierces an arrow. Dozens more coming, killing many of the contestants.]

Speaker: Vala
Text: Aloy! Go!

Speaker: Cultist Leader
Text: Keep them pinned down ’till the others arrive!

Speaker: Vala
Text: We can’t stay here! That’s the way out. But we won’t mate it under fire.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: They can’t shoot if they’re dead. Keep them busy, I’ll find an angle.

Speaker: Vala
Text: Bast! Bast, are you with us?!

Speaker: Bast
Text: I’m with you.

Speaker: Vala
Text: Let’s go, now!

Speaker: Bast
Text: Kill the invaders!
[The Cultist snipers shooting arrows from the high ground.]

Speaker: Nora Youth
Text: Too many of them! We can’t win!

Speaker: Bast
Text: Kill them!

Speaker: Nora Youth
Text: They’re too strong! We can’t top them!

Speaker: Vala
Text: Quick! Run for the slip-wire!
[Another wave of enemies coming. This time they attack directly.]

Speaker: Cultist Leader
Text: Kill the all! No witnesses! No survivors!

Speaker: Vala
Text: For All-Mother!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Okay, no more sneaking.

Speaker: Vala
Text: Now! Descend while we have a chance!
[Vala leads away the surviving contestants. Suddenly, a cultist with a machine gun appears and shoots them all...]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Vala!

Speaker: Bast
Text: Vala! No!

Speaker: Leader
Text: The Red-Hair dies now! Everyone FORWARD!
[Aloy kills everyone along with the leader with the machine gun. She goes to search the leader and finds the Focus. Then, muscular man comes up behind Aloy and grabs her by the throat.]

Speaker: Unknown Killer
Text: Turn your face to the sun, child.
[Suddenly, Rost appears and starts to fight with the killer. But… he dies.]

Speaker: Unknown Killer
Text: Burn it all. Then to your task.

Speaker: Attacker
Text: As you command.
[He sets fire to barrels of powder (apparently)]

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy! Survive!

[Rost throws her off a cliff and explodes along with the rest of the wounded. Some time passes. Aloy in feverish delirium drags on a stretcher along the corridor. Before her eyes flickers footage of her childhood.]

Speaker: Teersa
Text: She is doing!

Speaker: Lansra
Text: To take her there is blasphemy!

Speaker: Teersa
Text: She should be near her mother!

Speaker: Rost
Text: Aloy... I’m so sorry!

Speaker: Cultist Leader
Text: Turn your face to the sun, child.
[She wakes up.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Rost... No... No, no. I have to get out of here. I need my focus... no!  Rost saved me. They must have found me before I bled out. But why is no one here? Where am I?
[She finds her clothes nearby.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: My clothes - good. But where’s my Focus? Ah. It’s here. Okay. Wait? Am I inside the sacred mountain? But only Matriarchs are allowed inside. I don’t see my bow here. Or that damaged Focus, I took of that… killer. Where are they? I’m picking up some kind of signal. The Nora didn’t build this place - the Old Ones did. But why? It looks like the ruins I fell into when I was young.
[She finds new bow and her other equipment.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: There! With the rest of my things!

Speaker: Graphic
Text: Bow

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Now what can you show me?

Speaker: Unknown Killer
Text: All commanders: halt excavations, and proceed at once to the mission point.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You.

Speaker: Unknown Killer
Text: Avoid all contact with Nora savages - but if you are seen, kill every witness. Target imaging attached. Do not fail.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: “Target imaging?”

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Who says I’m like other Nora?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: They saw me through Olin’s Focus… How’s that possible?

Speaker: Unknown Woman
Text: Then make it quick. I’m heading in.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Hold for Identiscan.

Speaker: Unknown Woman
Text: You need to stop listening to Ted and start listening to me.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Where is this from? And when? Are you my mother?
[Image of and old woman that looks like Aloy appears. It has a subtitle – Terminate.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But why try to kill me because I look like you?
[Teersa enters.]

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Aloy! You are awake?!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You brought me here?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Quickly, you must follow!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: To where?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: To the place where you were born!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Are you saying I was born here - inside the Mountain?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: It is easier if I show you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why did you bring me here?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: It seemed you were dying, and to die near one’s mother is sacred. Lansra fought it, of course - but Jezza sided with me.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Is my mother here? Am I going to meet her?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: It’s complicated. Please, just follow me.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Does my mother look like me, but with short hair?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: I don’t see how that could be. You were not born of a woman. Aloy. The Mountain is your mother.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m - What?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What are you talking about?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Come.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What is this place?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: The Great Chamber, where All-Mother slew the Metal Devil… and gave birth to you. Aloy, the Proving massacre was just the first of many disasters. The war party we sent after the killers was ambushed and slaughtered.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But what does that have to do with where I was born?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: My hope is... everything! This is where we found you. We heard your cries, came to look, and there you were.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Just—just lying there?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Yes.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You mean I came from behind the door?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Always that is what I have believed - that you came from the Womb of the Mountain, a gift from All-Mother Herself. But others... like Lansra, feared that a darker power put you here... not a gift, but a curse.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But... this isn’t a Goddess.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Aloy!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It’s a door. With people behind it? My mother?

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Hold for Identiscan.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: The Goddess speaks!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It’s... just like the woman I saw...

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Error. Alpha Registry Corrupted. Identity cannot be confirmed. Entry denied.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: No. No! Please!

Speaker: Teersa
Text: All-Mother spoke to you! As if she knew you!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Were you not listening? It didn’t recognize me.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Because of corruption! The Goddess’s own words! Surely, if you heal this corruption, she will see you clearly!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And how would I do that?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: You said you’ve haul visions? Of a woman with short hair?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Yes. The killers came for me because I look like her.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: But their power is overwhelming! Is there no other trail to follow?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Olin! He was one of the outsiders, the night before the Proving. The killers saw me through his eyes. He lives in Meridian...

Speaker: Teersa
Text: So you will have to leave the sacred land...

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’ve been an outcast all my life. Why not an exile, too?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Shhh! There is another way. Come, and we will make it so.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You said the tribe is on the brink of extinction. What happened?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: After the massacre at the Proving, a great War Party was sent after the killers. Less than half survived.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: How was the War Party defeated?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: The killers do not fight alone. Somehow they have a power over the machines, corrupting them, driving them mad.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So the killers got away?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Yes. And now the on y plan my Sister Matriarchs can agree to is to sing the Hymn of Atonement and beg for All-Mother’s mercy! As though she would not want us to help ourselves!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Then what’s your plan?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: This! This was my plan! To show you where you were born and loose you to follow the destiny All-Mother intended for you! The other High Matriarchs are waiting for us. Let me do the talking.

Speaker: Jezza
Text: It is done?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Yes, I showed her. Sisters - the Goddess spoke to Aloy! Told her to heal the corruption!

Speaker: Lansra
Text: Hmmph.

Speaker: Jezza
Text: But, how is she to do that?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: She will have to journey beyond our Sacred Land.

Speaker: Jezza
Text: A Seeker. If the Goddess Spoke... it must be so.

Speaker: Lansra
Text: You would name this thing a Seeker?

Speaker: Jezza
Text: Sister!

Speaker: Teersa
Text: For once, Lansra, join with us.

Speaker: Lansra
Text: This will be your sin, not mine! Send her seeking and may she never be seen again.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Aloy, by the holy grace of the one Goddess, we hereby anoint you a Seeker of the Nora Tribe.

Speaker: Jezza
Text: No barrier can now stay you from your sacred task. May All-Mother protect you, and sustain you. Stay true. I will make ready for the Hymn. Our hopes lie with you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Teersa, what’s a “Seeker?”

Speaker: Teersa
Text: You are. And here is your Mark. In times of great need, the High Matriarchs may anoint a Seeker - a worthy brave sent forth to accomplish a great purpose. No matter where that purpose might take her.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Even beyond the borders of the sacred land?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Yes, and with the right to return when you are done - or as the need arises.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So I can go anywhere at all? No restrictions?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Even to forbidden places, like the Tainted Lands beyond All-Mother’s sight, or the ruins of the Metal World.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I see. Why are the lands beyond Nora territory called “tainted?”

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Is it not obvious? Our land is sacred. We live in sight of the one Goddess, All-Mother — source of all that lives. Beyond Her sight lies a vast fallen land, spiritually tainted. That is why it is against tribal law to leave. But the Seeker blessing will protect you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why are the “ruins of the metal world” forbidden?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: They are blighted places, Aloy - dark and wicked, like the Children of Metal who built them. When they rebelled and tried to murder All-Mother, Her wrath leveled their cities but could not cleanse their sin.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Their ancient spite haunts those ruins, ready to ensnare anyone foolish enough to enter them.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But... I’ve been in a ruin. It looked a lot like the inside of All-Mother.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: That cannot be so!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It is.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Then... this is something beyond my understanding. I will trust you to reveal the truth.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Have there been other Seekers?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: There have, but they are rare, and most who set out are never heard from again.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Was Rost a Seeker?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: No... not a Seeker...

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What are you not telling me?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: This is not the time, Aloy. Perhaps another day.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What was done with Rost’s body?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: I’m afraid there was... very little left to recover. But what there was, we buried at the place where he raised you, with ﬂowers on the grave.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Thank you. So many have suffered. Is there anything I can do to help?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: What is most important is for you to fulfill the purpose All-Mother has intended for you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I don’t know what that means any more than you do.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Then you must find out. If, however, you sense that part of your purpose is to help the tribe, by all means do so. I have no doubt you will find people in need throughout the Embrace.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You said the Nora sent a war party after the killers?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Yes, but it was ambushed and overrun. Very few escaped alive, and most that did were wounded.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Do you know where the killers went?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: No. But you could ask Varl, one of the braves guarding the Gates of the Embrace. He survived the ambush. He would know more.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I should be on my way.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: From here you must go to the Gates of the Embrace. Speak to Varl, and he will paint the way to Meridian. If any Nora tries to stand in your way, Aloy, make sure they know you are a Seeker.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I will. Thank you, Teersa, for all you’ve done.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: May All-Mother bless you and watch over you.
[Aloy go to the gate.]

Speaker: Seasoned Nora Brave
Text: The outcast approaches.

Speaker: Resh
Text: Ignore her. Continue the report.

Speaker: Seasoned Nora Brave
Text: There are rumors of a Demon loose in the Embrace a thing of dark metal that corrupts every Machine it touches.

Speaker: Resh
Text: Where did it come from?

Speaker: Seasoned Nora Brave
Text: They say it broke through the Gates of the Embrace.

Speaker: Resh
Text: Who is “they”? Varl’s a fool to defend that Gate. It is here at mother’s Watch that we will make our stand.

Speaker: Seasoned Nora Brave
Text: Varl and his followers, they tried to stop it, but the Demon was too fast, too powerful. So far eight groups have arrived from Mother’s Heart to join the Hymn of Atonement, and more are on the way.

Speaker: Resh
Text: Good. All true Nora will lift their voices in song.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Teb?
[She goes to talk to Teb.]

Speaker: Teb
Text: I heard the rumors, but I didn’t know for sure until saw you just now. I’m glad to see you’re okay.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What sort of rumors did you hear?

Speaker: Teb
Text: That you were wounded, expected to die. And then High Matriarch Teersa insisted that you be healed inside All-Mother! Oh, that caused a stir! Only Matriarchs are allowed to enter the Mountain! But - you deserved the honor. The survivors had told everyone how you fought to save them!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I wasn’t the only one to fight.

Speaker: Teb
Text: No. They spoke of Bast and Vala, too.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And Rost. The man who raised me. He fought to save me, and he died for it.

Speaker: Teb
Text: The survivors didn’t speak of him. But I remember him. He was there, that day when you saved me. I remember he stepped in front of you when my father started yelling. If by dying he saved your life, Aloy, I don’t think he regretted it.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I need the gate opened.

Speaker: Teb
Text: Do you have any idea how dangerous it is out there?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I need to pass through.

Speaker: Teb
Text: You’ll have to talk to Resh, then, up on the wall. He’s the new War Chief. I’m not sure he’ll help you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What’s the danger in the Embrace? Are the killers still there?

Speaker: Teb
Text: No, they’re long gone The War Party went after them... but the killers slaughtered them. They have some… evil power over the Machines. They corrupt them, make them fight at their side.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And these corrupted machines they’re loose in the Embrace?

Speaker: Teb
Text: Some have broken through. And from what I hear, it’s even worse outside the Embrace. Believe me, this is no time to go traveling.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why wouldn’t Resh help me?

Speaker: Teb
Text: Well, he says... mean things about you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That I’m a motherless curse, an outcast, that sort of thing?

Speaker: Teb
Text: Yeah. I wish he hadn’t been made War Chief, but Sona disappeared after the ambush. They say she went after the killers all by herself.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Who is Sona?

Speaker: Teb
Text: Sona was the tribe’s War Chief, but she went missing after the War Party was ambushed. You probably saw her at Mother’s Heart. A tall, lean woman with dark skin and long, white hair? Her daughter ran in the Proving... but, she died.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Was Vala her daughter?

Speaker: Teb
Text: Yes, she was. I liked her.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So did I. What are you doing here with a bow and spear, Teb? You’re a “Stitcher,” not a Brave.

Speaker: Teb
Text: Most of our Braves are dead or wounded Aloy. Someone has to defend Mother’s Watch, so... I thought I’d help out. I should be okay... just as long as I don’t try to run any Brave Trails, right?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I should be on my way, Teb.

Speaker: Teb
Text: May All-Mother protect.
[She goes to Resh.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I need the gate opened.

Speaker: Resh
Text: Since when has any outcast’s “need" been my concern?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I recognize you from the Proving. You saw Bast shatter my trophy, and you did nothing.

Speaker: Resh
Text: You would speak ill of the dead? Truly you have no shame.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I nearly put an arrow through your eye.

Speaker: Resh
Text: And you threaten me, in front of witnesses? When the High Matriarchs hear of this, you’ll be an outcast all over again.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I have been anointed a Seeker. So open the gate.

Speaker: Resh
Text: You - a Seeker? Have Teersa and Jezza gone insane?! Bad enough that they let you run in the Proving! But to nurse you back to health inside the Sacred Mountain? No wander a curse is upon us, and children he dead under cairns of stone.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: How can you be so heartless? I fought beside those children, shoulder to shoulder and back to back. I saw them fall.

Speaker: Resh
Text: If even one of them had been true Nora, they would’ve put an arrow in your back!

Speaker: Seasoned Nora Brave
Text: Resh! Come on.

Speaker: Resh
Text: Silence! I am your War Chief!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And I am a Seeker, anointed by the High Matriarchs. So open the gate, and I will be on my way.

Speaker: Resh
Text: The sooner you’re gone from here, the better.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What was that?!
[She saw giant machine with a herd of Striders.]

Speaker: Nora Brave
Text: The Demon!

Speaker: Resh
Text: Sound the alarm!
[The Demon enslaves Striders.]

Speaker: Nora Brave
Text: By the Goddess, what is it doing to them?

Speaker: Resh
Text: Brace yourselves! What have you brought on us now, you motherless curse? Kill them, braves! Kill them all! Braves - ready yourselves! Today we fight a curse! A Demon! All-Mother, give us Strength!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Won’t be long… got to get in position.

Speaker: Resh
Text: Attack!
[Aloy kills “the demon” - Corruptor.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Here it comes!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It’s down!

Speaker: Seasoned Nora Brave
Text: The Demon is dead!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: One of this things marched with the killers at the Proving... How does it possess other machines? What is its secret? How does a machine like that take control of all those Striders?
[Aloy examines Corruptior’s carcass.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: How did you do it? Show me. You made them obey you. But how? This. You did this with this. It’s... connecting to my focus. Then - I could use this? It’s worth a shot. Couple loops of wire… Looks like it’ll hold. I just need to test it.

Speaker: Teb
Text: Aloy! How did you do that? You killed that demon... pulled its guts from the carcass!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The way it controls other machines - I think I’ve figured it out. But I need to test it on a machine.

Speaker: Teb
Text: Uh... plenty of Striders along the path to the Gates of the Embrace. I guess...

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Exactly. And the Gates are where I’ll be headed anyway. I need to speak to Varl.

Speaker: Teb
Text: I always knew you were different, Aloy. But...

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But what.

Speaker: Teb
Text: I think you’re a blessing from All-Mother! No matter what Resh says!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Thank you, Teb. But I have to go now.

Speaker: Teb
Text: I know you do. And my thoughts go with you. Good luck out there. Stay safe.

Speaker: Resh
Text: Braves! I want that gate repair immediately! I don’t care if you bandage it together, get it done!
[Aloy go outside the Gates.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I need to test this device. See What it can do.
[Aloy finds a herd of Striders.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Striders. I can test the Override device on them. Should go in quiet. Didn’t go through all of this to wind up trampled by a frightened herd. Nice and quiet. Okay, here it goes! Come on, come on… It worked! It’s not hostile... Seems almost tame. I think I could ride it! There we go. Thattaboy. That’s more like it. Ya! This Strider is fast! This beats walking! I should try overriding other kinds of machines! Probably can’t ride them all, but I might find a use for them!
[She rides to the Mother’s Embrace Gate.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Sounds of fighting just outside the gates?

Speaker: Varl
Text: Watch yourselves!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The gates look shattered!

Speaker: Varl
Text: Bring it closer! Closer!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Varl I take it?

Speaker: Varl
Text: Aloy. The outcast who won the Proving. So you survived your wounds!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: High Matriarch Teersa said you might know the way to Meridian.

Speaker: Varl
Text: The capital of the Carja Sundom?! You seek exile?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: No -- a traitor named Olin. The Matriachs made me a Seeker, so I could go after him.

Speaker: Varl
Text: Then you should head north, to Mother’s Crown. If you make it, talk to Marea. She’ll point the way.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: "If" I make it?

Speaker: Varl
Text: The trail is dangerous. Ever since the War Party massacre, our lands go unpatrolled, and our borders unguarded. We have no War-Chief to lead us.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Isn’t that Resh’s job?

Speaker: Varl
Text: Pheh. Only because Sona went missing. I’d go after her myself, but she ordered me to hold this gate with my life. And so I have.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You said the trail is dangerous What sort of dangers?

Speaker: Varl
Text: Almost too many to name. The killers are still out there, and somehow they’ve corrupted the machines – spreading madness!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Yes, I’ve seen it myself.

Speaker: Varl
Text: Bandits, too. Cut-throats who snuck across the border to prey on us. Word is, there’s a camp in the metal ruins upriver.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Sounds like I need to craft more arrows. You said I won the Proving. How did you know that?

Speaker: Varl
Text: I spoke to survivors. They said you fought bravely. As did Bast... and my sister.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Your sister was Vala? ...I’m very sorry. I... liked her. I think we might even have become friends… If we’d had a chance.

Speaker: Varl
Text: Thank you. She died saving others. There is no better death.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You said the War Party was massacred. How?

Speaker: Varl
Text: When word came of the attack on the Proving, War-Chief Sona assembled a War Party to give chase. But in their haste to get vengeance, some braves broke rank and raced ahead, straight into a trap. A pack of crazed machines, seething With corruption, fell upon the braves and, savaged them gone. And our losses were... extreme.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You said War-Chief Sona is missing?

Speaker: Varl
Text: Even when the War Party was massacred, she wouldn’t give up the chase. She called for volunteers and went after the killers.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You didn’t volunteer?

Speaker: Varl
Text: Of course I did. But Sona... denied me that. She ordered me to see the wounded back to the Embrace… and to guard this gate -- to guard the Embrace -- with my life. That was days ago, and since then, there’s been no word from her.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So there’s no way to know if she’s alive or dead?

Speaker: Varl
Text: If anyone could survive out there, it would be her. Sona’s prowess is legend. An unbending spear to measure ourselves against.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Sounds like she sets a high standard.

Speaker: Varl
Text: Oh, you have no idea. She’s my mother.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I should be on my way.

Speaker: Varl
Text: Aloy... Before you make the journey to Mother’s Crown and beyond... is there any chance you could search for Sona? The tribe needs her leadership. I’d go after her myself, If she hadn’t commanded me to hold this gate at all costs.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Where was she last seen?

Speaker: Varl
Text: The War Party massacre site. A wooded hollow across from Devil’s Thirst, on this side of the river. You might be able to pick up her trail there. She went after the killers who attacked the Proving, who killed those we love, who tried to kill you...

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I get it, Varl. I’ll see what I can do.
[He notices Aloy’s tamed Strider.]

Speaker: Varl
Text: A Strider! How is that possible?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It’s hard to explain. Something I... discovered.

Speaker: Varl
Text: ...I see.
[Aloy goes to Mother’s Crown to meet with Marea.]

Speaker: Marea
Text: Here she is. The hero of Devil’s Grief. Come here, girl. Been wanting to meet you. So, you’re Aloy. I’ve heard about you from the war-party. The hero of Devil’s Grief.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: One of them, maybe. I didn’t fight alone. You’re Marea? Varl told me you’d to know the way to Meridian.

Speaker: Marea
Text: The Carja capital? West will take you to it, but their soldiers will stop you long before you get there.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: They can try.

Speaker: Marea
Text: No. What I mean is, there’s a Carja fort that guards the pass between east and west. Word is, the Carja have sealed the gate, out of fear of the corrupted machines infesting our Secret Land.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So if I clear out the corrupted machines, they’ll open the border?

Speaker: Marea
Text: I suppose. But I can’t spare any braves to help you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Who said I needed help?

Speaker: Marea
Text: You’ll clear the valley - all by yourself?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m good with my bow.

Speaker: Marea
Text: For you sake, better than good, I hope.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So I’ll find this Carja fort to the west? And beyond that, Meridian?

Speaker: Marea
Text: Yes. The Carja call the place "Daytower." It’s not far from the forsaken village.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What forsaken village?

Speaker: Marea
Text: It had a name once, not that it matters now. I was born there.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What happened to it?

Speaker: Marea
Text: The war. The Carja destroyed it in one of their Red Raids. I was fifteen at the time. I got away. Others weren’t so lucky. The Nora withdrew to this place, Mother’s Crown. Relinquished our claim on the valley. Even now, with the war behind us, we’ve left the valley be, a kind of... buffer between the Sundom and our Sacred Land.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: How far has the corruption spread?

Speaker: Marea
Text: I’ve seen it myself in machines on the head of the valley. And there’s been word of corrupted machines in the south, too. Whatever the corruption is, it doesn’t just affect machines. It burns flesh and sickens the injured.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Do the corrupted machines have any weaknesses?

Speaker: Marea
Text: Fire seems to affect them more than ordinary machines. A small mercy. This is a curse only the Goddess can you lift.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Unless we find out what’s behind it, and put a stop to it.

Speaker: Marea
