Text: No other Oseram had the motive and ingenuity to lure Ersa into this trap. I expect to find him lurking somewhere near the border. I’ve already sent an agent to investigate. He’ll be waiting for word from us at the marketplace in Pitchcliff.

Speaker: Avad
Text: I can’t move troops to the border without provoking the Oseram. But I could send a few Vanguardsmen - and perhaps an exceptionally gifted Nora as well? Erend, Marad - let me discuss it with her privately.
[They leave.]

Speaker: Avad
Text: I hate to impose further after all you’ve done. But if this is a matter of great importance to me.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It sounds like Ersa means a lot to you.

Speaker: Avad
Text: Without her Oseram Vanguard I would not have been able to liberate Meridian and end my father’s brutal reign. Since then, it has been difficult to maintain the peace between our tribes, but Ersa has a way of making her people see reason. So you is I need her back at my side - and quickly.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Who is Dervahl, exactly?

Speaker: Avad
Text: To understand Dervahl, you must first understand my father. He truly thought of himself as a Sun God. His mind was... broken. He believed that blood sacrifice would solve... well, everything. So he raided the other tribes for victims, especially the Oseram. Dervahl fought back. He crafted powerful weapons and rallied his people. My father responded with the ultimate cruelty. He captured Dervahl’s wife and daughter and sacrificed them in the, Sun Ring.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So why would Dervahl go to so much trouble to kidnap Ersa?

Speaker: Avad
Text: He felt she betrayed him. She fought by his side until she realized he planned to raze Meridian and butcher its people. Then she came to me. Together, we stopped him... and liberated the city from my father. Dervahl has spent every moment since trying to get revenge, mostly on the other Oseram who fought with us. He made so many powerful enemies, I thought we had seen the last of him. I was wrong.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The killers who attacked the Nora - I’ve discovered that they’re a faction of Shadow Carja called the Eclipse. They’re digging up ancient weapons - machines that corrupt and control other machines. They use them to strike Meridian.

Speaker: Avad
Text: What you’re saying echoes reports I’ve received from Marad. A Shadow Carja splinter group. Corrupted machines across the land. When will this attack come, do you know?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m not exactly sure.

Speaker: Avad
Text: Then we will do what we can to prepare, but in the meantime, Ersa is my highest priority. Please help me find her.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’d like to ask you something about the Sundom and its politics.

Speaker: Avad
Text: By all means.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: They call you a Sun God who killed his own father in order to unite the tribes in harmony. Is any of it true?

Speaker: Avad
Text: They say you can see the invisible, split an arrow at fifty paces, and tame machines at a glance. How much of that is true?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It’s not too far off.

Speaker: Avad
Text: Well, I would like to unite the tribes in harmony. But you saw how many courtiers I have to deal with first. Maybe next week.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Quite a place you’ve got here. You can almost see the little people below the mesa.

Speaker: Avad
Text: You don’t approve? Well, I have a secret for you. Neither do I. But we must be patient. Change won’t come in a single sunrise.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But will it happen at all, while men live in palaces?

Speaker: Avad
Text: It might. Eventually. If people like you help me bring it about.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Your politics seem very complicated. The Oseram are friends, but enemies, too?

Speaker: Avad
Text: I couldn’t have liberated Meridian without the help of Ersa and her Oseram freebooters. Many of them are settled here. But the Ealdorman of the Oseram clans in the Claim have become jealous of their success. So have many Carja nobles. It’s a volatile situation, especially given the fact that my father raided the Oseram for years. Ersa helps keep the peace, promising a future based on mutual gain. But some, like Dervahl, will never let go of their venom.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I need to get going.

Speaker: Avad
Text: I know. Well, they say kings should never beg - but please, help me find Ersa.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Who says that?

Speaker: Avad
Text: Marad, for one. Don’t hesitate to ask him or Erend if you have further questions.
[Aloy begins her long journey to the north.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: This must be Pitchcliff. Marad’s agent should be at the marketplace by now.

Speaker: Erend
Text: No sign of Marad’s guy? He’s had plenty of time to investigate.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: We’d better look for him.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Damn right.
[Soon they find a body.]

Speaker: Erend
Text: Has to be Marad’s guy. Dervahl’s thugs must have made him.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Maybe because he found something. Look at this. I think he drew a map with his own blood.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Right. Those kind of maps you know you’d better follow.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That might be Pitchcliff. Can Mark a spot to the north. Could be Dervahl’s location.

Speaker: Erend
Text: My men are waiting outside of town. I’ll grab them and meet you there.
[Aloy ride to Dervahl’s camp.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Machines. Looks like they’ve been chained up.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Dervahl’s a tinker. He probably experiments on them, or strips them for parts.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Maybe I can use them to make some trouble I’ll go in first. Hold off until the fighting starts.

Speaker: Erend
Text: All right. We’ve got your back.

[Aloy shoot the chains and angry machines kill half the guards in the camp. Aloy kills the other half. She finds some basement, in which there is a powerful speaker, which makes a vile and loud sound that prevents you from entering. A heavy-armed soldier comes out of the basement. Apparently nasty sound does not bother him.]

Speaker: Oseram Heavy
Text: Dervahl says you gotta eat dirt.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Okay.
[She kill the heavy.]

Speaker: Erend
Text: Ersa must be in there! We have to get through!
[Aloy search the heavy and find an ear plugs.]

Speaker: Aldy
Text: They must use these to protect themselves from that awful sound.
[Inside the basement the heroes find Ersa. She is being tortured by some kind of sound cannon.]

Speaker: Erend
Text: Ersa!
[He breaks the cannon with his hammer.]

Speaker: Ersa
Text: Erend? Dervahl tried to break me. Shows what he knows.

Speaker: Erend
Text: I should have been with you. Why didn’t you come for me? I know I’m a useless drunk, but-

Speaker: Ersa
Text: No, idiot. I got a message from Dervahl, saying he wanted to parley. I didn’t come for you because I knew it was a trap. Couldn’t let you get hurt. Just didn’t think it’d be that good a trap. Thought I could take him out.  Now lisen. Dervahl’s planning something big in Meridian. He said he’d “force Avad to watch as the smoke darkens their precious sun.” Your king needs you. No more playing around - you’re going to have to grow up fast.

Speaker: Erend
Text: I will. I promise.

Speaker: Ersa
Text: You damn well better, little brother.
[She dies.]

Speaker: Erend
Text: Ersa? No. Please. I won’t let you down I promise.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Erend, I’m so sorry.

Speaker: Erend
Text: We’ve got to find Dervahl, but Meridian’s a big place.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’ll look rough his things. Maybe we can narrow it down.
[She find some kind of an old audio recorder.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Such a strange device. Beautifully crafted. What happens when I turn it on? Dervahl’s records, maybe?
[She find a box with modifications.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Just notes about crafting… hmm… and a letter tucked between the pages. Lots of Blaze, headed to Meridian. If we find it, I’ll bet we find Dervahl, too. This Machine’s been picked apart with precision. What’s Dervahl learned from all his tinkering? Do I even want to know?
[She goes back to Erend.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I think I found something that can help. Let’s head back to the Palace.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Go. I won’t be long, but I need to tend to my sister.
[Aloy returns to Meridian and goes to the Sun King audience.]

Speaker: Erend
Text: I’ve sent a messenger to the Claim to let everyone know.

Speaker: Avad
Text: If there’s anything you or your clan need for her arrangements, you need but ask.

Speaker: Erend
Text: There’ll be time for all that later.

Speaker: Avad
Text: Aloy. I’m glad you’re back. I’m at a loss about Ersa. To learn she lives, then lose that hope seems cruel.

Speaker: Erend
Text: She wouldn’t want us to waste time talking. She’d want us to find Dervahl. She said he raved about “smoke darkening the sun.” Tell them what you found in the papers.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: A letter. It mentioned a shipment of Blaze being sent to a warehouse here. Only it wasn’t addressed to Dervahl. The name was Aelund Forgeman. Does that mean anything to you?

Speaker: Blameless Marad
Text: Hmm. It sounds familiar... yes - a landlord. The Qseram have been buying up buildings across the city including one under that name. Let me think. It’s by the edge of the mesa, near the temple. It used to be a shop, but it could serve as a warehouse. If Dervahl used the name as an alias to buy it, he might even be there now.

Speaker: Erend
Text: I’ll round up my man.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’ll meet you there.

Speaker: Blameless Marad
Text: Erend, wait. Remember that no one hates Dervahl more than your own tribe. The Clans would give up much to obtain him.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Take him alive? So you can haggle over him? You can’t be serious!

Speaker: Avad
Text: Our security depends on keeping the peace. If the opportunity presents itself, take him alive. Consider that a command. Aloy, a moment, please.
[Erend and Marad leaves.]

Speaker: Avad
Text: When we spoke, Erend didn’t wish to dwell on the... details... of Ersa’s death. Understandable, of course. But now that that they’ve been left to my imagination, those details are all I can think about. You were there. Did she suffer?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: She’s not the one who’s suffering now. You are. She died before you could say goodbye.

Speaker: Avad
Text: Is it that obvious? You’re right, I’m dwelling on my pain, not just hers. And there is only one thing left that can help. Find Dervahl and bring him before me. He will answer for his crimes. Don’t let me delay you any longer. Meet Erend at the warehouse.
[Aloy finds the warehouse. At the same moment, Erend and his men, armed and armored, also fit in.]

Speaker: Erend
Text: This is the place. You home, Dervahl? Got a surprise for you!
[Kicks the door out.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Or he has a surprise for us.
[There are a few exploding barrels on the floor on which the blaze is dripping from the top floor.]

Speaker: Erend
Text: Is it a bomb? Doesn’t look too big.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Big enough to kill us.

Speaker: Erend
Text: All right. I’ll shut up.
[Aloy is examining the warehouse with her Focus.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: If I try to take t apart a booby trap will set it off. Blaze. It must be leaking from something upstairs. If that bomb goes off, this Blaze will ignite in a firestorm.

Speaker: Erend
Text: That’s a lot of Blaze.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: If that bomb downstairs goes off, it’ll be just what Dervahl promised. Smoke will darken the sun... as the city goes up in flames. There’s got to be a way to stop it. Maybe there is some way I can open this window to get rid of the fuel for the bomb. Looks like a wooden bracket. Not very strong.
[She opens a window next to the barrels.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Help me push this out.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Okay. Brute force. I’m good at that. What will it do?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Save the city, I hope. But when the Blaze falls, run for it, because the booby-trap on the bomb downstairs is going to get set off.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Uh… will we survive?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Probably not. Now push.
[They throw away the blaze and the warehouse explodes. Erend and Aloy barely manage to get out of it.]

Speaker: Erend
Text: We did it! Dervahl’s best shot, and Meridian’s still standing!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: This isn’t over. Dervahl said he’d make Avad watch.

Speaker: Erend
Text: No way. To do that, he’d have to get into the palace - and that’s too heavily guarded.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Get back there, just to be sure I’m going to look around. Maybe Dervahl’s men left something behind when they planted that bomb.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Got it. Don’t worry - if he tries for the palace, he’s finished.
[Aloy investigate the area.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Boot tracks - with a just a bit of Blaze in them.
[She follows the tracks.]

Speaker: Carja Artisan
Text: What happened?

Speaker: Carja Artisan
Text: I haven’t heard a blast like that since the liberation!

Speaker: Carja Villager
Text: There’s smoke rising from the edge of the Mesa!

Speaker: Carja Villager
Text: Are we under attack?
[Aloy walks into one of Meridian’s houses.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The tracks lead inside - another one of Dervahl’s hideouts? This must be where Dervahl assembled the detonator. Ugh. He tunneled through the wall. Dervahl did find a way into the palace!
[As she walked out of the house through a broken wall, she saw Dervahl and his men standing on the bridge leading to the palace.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Dervahl.

Speaker: Mercenary Warrior
Text: Wish I could be there to see the “Sun God” on his knees.
[Aloy’s sneaking into the palace. Dervahl tries Avad, Erend and the guards with his sonic weapon.]

Speaker: Dervahl
Text: Look at you, Avad - the wriggling runt of a maniac king. You robbed me of my right to kill your father, so I’ll have to settle for you. I’m going to enjoy watching the Carja bum - even more because you’ll be watching with me. Say goodbye to Meridian, Avad. Breathe in the stench and choke on the ashes.
[He clicks on the detonator but nothing happens.]

Speaker: Dervahl
Text: Something’s wrong-- I didn’t... didn’t hear anything...

Speaker: Oseram Outlander
Text: There’s a bit of smoke rising from the mesa’s edge!

Speaker: Dervahl
Text: No! It should be a firestorm, not some belch from a charcoal-burner!
[He and his men are leaving. Aloy turns off the sonic weapon and follows him.]

Speaker: Dervahl
Text: What’s this? Oh. You must be the Nora who bushwhacked my camp.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And disabled your bomb.

Speaker: Dervahl
Text: Did you now? Well, bomb or no bomb. I’m going to splatter that throne with blood - first yours, then Avad’s!
[He picks up a some heavy weapon. The adrenaline battle in a narrow space begins.]

Speaker: Dervahl
Text: Why does Avad always have his ladies do the fighting? Can we finish this? I’ve got a Sun God to kill! You’ll have to do better than that, red! It’s not over yet, Nora. Any good Oseram tinker will tell you - always have a third plan!
[He calls on several bird machines.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Saw me. Here we go.

Speaker: Dervahl
Text: Ah, those majestic, murderous Glinthawks! Never do the work if you can get a machine to do it for you!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: With the modifications I made to my spear, I can override Glinthawks.

Speaker: Dervahl
Text: I hope you like fighting these things, because there’s more on the way!
[Aloy destroy them all.]

Speaker: Erend
Text: As much as I wish Ersa was here to kill you, I don’t mind doing it for her.

Speaker: Dervahl
Text: Go ahead. I’m not afraid - except that knowing you, Erend, you’ll screw it up.
[Avad and his guards approach.]

Speaker: Erend
Text: I know what you are afraid of - going back to Mainspring in chains. Every Clan in the Claim wants you dead - and they know how to make it hurt. They’ll even bid for the privilege.

Speaker: Dervahl
Text: It’s just like you to get someone else to do your killing.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Shut up. You’re at the Sun-King’s mercy now.
[He smack him with the handle of his hammer.]

Speaker: Avad
Text: Aloy, to say you have my gratitude feels woefully insufficient. You saved my life. You saved Meridian. And because of you, there will be justice for Ersa’s murder. We can mourn her knowing the truth, without painful uncertainty. It’s hard to imagine where we’d be without you - and I don’t want to try. I hope you will consider staying in Meridian.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Were you and Ersa, you know...?

Speaker: Avad
Text: I suppose it’s obvious how I feel... how I felt about her. She didn’t just give me advice. She gave me strength. But we couldn’t be together. Relations between the Carja and Oseram in Meridian were unsteady as it was. The union of the Sun-King and an Oseram warrior would have lead to open revolt in the city, and probably war with the clans.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Did anyone know?

Speaker: Avad
Text: Only one - Dervahl. He wanted Ersa, but she rejected him. And so jealousy became yet another of his hateful motivations.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What exactly will happen to Dervahl?

Speaker: Avad
Text: For now, he’ll languish in one of the old cells under the Sun-Ring here in Meridian As for what happens after we negotiate his extradition to Mainspring. I don’t want to think about My father was very creative when it came to inflicting suffering, but some Oseram devices surpass even his imaginings. What a waste. Dervahl is a brilliant man. I wonder what he would have accomplished if it weren’t for my father’s cruelty.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I know who attacked the Nora - a faction of Shadow Carja called the Eclipse. They’re digging up ancient machines, weapons they want to use to strike Meridian.

Speaker: Avad
Text: I see what you’re saying echoes whispers I’ve heard from Marad. A Shadow Carja splinter group. Corrupted machines across the land.

Speaker: Avad
Text: When will the attack come, do you know?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m not sure yet.

Speaker: Avad
Text: Then we will do what we can to prepare. Keep me informed if you learn more.
[She’s visiting Dervahl that already in a cell.]

Speaker: Dervahl
Text: Come to gloat, Nora? Well, as you can see, I’m busy. I get it, you want to rub it in. Well, it’s not working. Ha ha. It’s funny to pester the tinker in the cage. What a laugh. You think that bit of crap on your brow makes you smart? I’ll bet you couldn’t have taken apart my bomb without it. Think I’m done? Think again. I’ve gotten out of worse scrapes. While the lunkheads in Mathspring dither over how to kill me I’ll dig myself out Just you wait. When I get out of here, I’m going to plant a Thunderjaw log in your bedroll. Got to admit it burns me that a save tracked me down. Most Nora get confused by anything more than two sticks and a string. Don’t you have something better to do? Like choke on a Lancehorn? You think that spear of yours is so fancy, but I could craft it blindfolded, during a quick nap. Riding machines? And supposed to be impressed? Get one to serve me lunch, then I’ll take notice. You’re like a burr in a boot you know that? Just... so... irritating. Hammer to Steel, hate you.
[Then she goes to see Erend.]

Speaker: Erend
Text: Aloy. I was just thinking about Ersa. She would have killed Dervahl on the spot. I know it. That’s why she went out to meet him in the first place - to put him down. But she also told me to grow up. Got to admit it burned a little when she said it. But I’m trying to take it to heart. And I guess growing up means putting what you should do in front of what you want to do, right?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You’re asking me? I’m pretty sure you’re older.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Yeah, but I don’t act like it, do I?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You did with Dervahl.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Don’t give me too much credit. Part of me still wants to wait for a quiet moment and wring his neck.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Yeah, but you won’t. Because you’re a good Captain.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Come on, stop. You’re going to make me tear up.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So after all this, what’s next for Erend Vanguardsman?

Speaker: Erend
Text: Heading back to the Claim for a while. I’ll get in touch with my clan, and we’ll lay Ersa to rest properly. Like how she would have wanted. And by that I mean - less chit-chat, more drinking.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What do you think the Oseram will do to Dervahl?

Speaker: Erend
Text: First off, they’ll argue about it for a long time. But whatever they come up with, it won’t be quick, I can live with that. In fact, I might just drop by his cell under the Sun-Ring to remind him what’s coming.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Well.

Speaker: Erend
Text: I know, you’ve got to go. Killers to track Machines to master - all before breakfast. You know what? When we met, I thought I was a big shot talking to a pretty girl hidden away in the middle of nowhere. Now I see that I was just lucky to get a minute of your time. Try not to forget about me while you’re out there changing the world.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’ll always have a minute for you. Maybe even two.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Two? Ha. She likes me.
[Aloy climbs a snow-covered mountain and kills the cultists that have settled there. A picture of a huge metal octopus, broken thousands of years ago, opens before her.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The Grave-Hoard. In the shadow of a Metal Devil. Great.
[She gets inside an ancient building.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Going down fast! They’re inside, too! That does it. Time to take a look around the room. A battle... frozen in ice, and time. Are you getting this Sylens? Sylens? Sylens, you getting this?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: What is it?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: All these soldiers, they died here.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: People die all the time. Now keep going, and find something interesting.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Tch! “Operation: Enduring Victory.” What did that mean? Whatever it was, doesn’t seem to have turned out very well.
[She’s going down the rope and she’s starting to look around the building.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Must’ve been where the soldiers slept? Like the lodge in Mother’s Heart, I guess. What was this place? The furnishings were... metal? How’d they ever get comfortable? It was the “Metal World.” Guess they were used to it. Just one bed. Maybe their war chief’s room? Red Light. Guess that means no power. Useful information. These wires must run to the power source. A holographic interface. Must be some kind of code. Maybe I should try scanning objects in this area.
[She finds a diary.]

Speaker: Geo-Thermal Maintenance Tech
Text: Hey, y’all wanted to know how I remember the geo-therm system reboot. Goes like this. Bird flies north in summer, east in spring, west in fall, and south in winter. Didn’t expect to hear nature poetry from the lips of Mike the GT tech did you? As usual, I defy expectations...
[She restores the power and gets in some sort of barracks.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: More Eclipse. Must be another way in. It’s them, all right. They’re not looking for answers. Just weapons.
[She finds some kind of meeting room.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What... is this?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: That? It’s a map.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: A map of - what?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Our world. The planet Earth, Aloy. It’s not flat, like you thought.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why would I think that? During eclipses, the shadow cast on the moon is curved. So our world is a globe? And it looks like this from a distance?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: We’ll discuss this another time. Back to the matter at hand.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The Faro robots were spreading across the world, eating everything up. Somehow, Elisabet stopped them before it was too late. But how?
[Behind the next door he finds a hangar.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The Eclipse, tampering with the Metal Devil… They don’t think they can wake it, do they?

Speaker: Cultist Thug
Text: Watch out!

Speaker: Cultist Dredger
Text: Sun and shadow!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Another "Khopesh!" And this one can move!
[She kills the cultist and destroy the Deathbringer.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That did it. So the soldiers long ago... they had to fight hundreds of those, all at once?
[She enters the War Room and activates the projector. The room is filled with ghosts of the days that long gone - holographic projections.]

Speaker: General Herres
Text: Thank you, Dr. Sobeck. You can take a seat.

Speaker: Military Commander
Text: Hah! You’re going to thank her?! After what she just said?!

Speaker: General Herres
Text: Dr. Sobeck has made the situation very clear, General - and given us an option. We should all be thanking her.

Speaker: Military Commander
Text: It’s just... I mean... my god. Maybe take this discussion offline?

Speaker: General Herres
Text: There’s not going to be any discussion. You saw the numbers. Now Faro, he’ll foot the bill, but his money can’t buy the time necessary to complete Zero Dawn. That... can only be paid for in blood.

Speaker: Military Commander
Text: Oh, come on!

Speaker: Military Commander 2
Text: If we upgrade our fleet, crack the codes somehow-!

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: Were you not listening?! Robots can’t do the fighting for you this time! When it comes to hacking this rogue swarm is an apex predator! Anything automated you throw at it, they will hijack and take over!

Speaker: Military Commander
Text: But this? We’d be throwing civilians into a meat grinder!

Speaker: General Herres
Text: Commanders! The enemy we’re facing self-replicates faster than we can kill it, and it eats biomass as fuel! Zero Dawn is all we’ve got.

Speaker: Military Commander 2
Text: So we put a rail gun in the hand of every civilian strong enough to carry one, show them where the trigger is, and point them to the front? How the hell do we sell that?

Speaker: General Herres
Text: By giving them something to fight for. Zero Dawn. The top-secret super-weapons program that will save us - so long as humanity holds off the swarm long enough for Dr. Sobeck and her team to finish it. The file I’m sending contains the war plan for Operation: Enduring Victory.

Speaker: Military Commander
Text: War plan? This is a war crime.

Speaker: General Herres
Text: It may be ugly - but it’s something. Consider the alternative. Dr. Sobeck. I’ve secured use of a decommissioned Orbital Launch Base outside Bryce, Utah as the Zero Dawn staging area. Plenty of space there. When can you get started?

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: I’ve already mailed you a list of Alpha and Beta candidates. Most are foreign nationals or subjects of corporate holdings, so extracting them...

Speaker: General Herres
Text: Leave that to me. You’ll get your dream team. Count on it.

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: Then I’ll be off.
[The projection ends.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Orbital Launch Base? What is that? What did these people do? What did Elisabet do?
[She climbs outside the building.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Glad to be rid of that place. Now I just need to find the Orbital Launch Base they talked about.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: I’ve checked my data and located the base. That’s the good news.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And the bad?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: It’s directly underneath the Citadel. The palace at Sunfall.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The capital of the Shadow Carja? Not exactly convenient.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: The palace is crawling with Eclipse agents, many in positions of authority, all of them wearing Focuses. The moment they see you, Hades will, too. He’ll issue another kill order - and this time the entire Shadow Carja military will be after you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So disable their Focuses. You’ve done it before.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: It’s not that simple. Too many Focuses in one place... each of them communicating with each other and back to Hades - a whole network of them.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: "Network?" What’s that?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Imagine a vast, invisible web, stretched across the land from end to end, connecting Focuses together, allowing them to communicate over vast distances instantaneously.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: All right. So... is there some way to cut the web down?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Hmm. Crash the network. Audacious. Yes - there is a way. A weak point in the network.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Point the way.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Heh. I’ll send the location data to your Focus. Head there, and I’ll be in touch when you’re close with more directions.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What was Zero Dawn? What sort of super-weapon did Elisabet make? She stopped the machines, but not before the world she knew – the civilization – ended. Now how am I going to get down from here? Oh, this should be quite the ride.
[Aloy goes to the other side of the world and finds a small gorge...]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: There are the hand-holds - right where you said they’d be. Did you get that, Sylens? No? Fitting name you got there.
[She climbs the escarpment.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: All right. What now?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: You wait that’s what. Take a seat at the camp fire and rest. When night falls, we’ll talk.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: At least I’ll have a fire to keep me company.
[She sits down at the fire and waits until the evening.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: How nice of you to finally drop by.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Our purpose this night is to crash the Focus network.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Yeah. Tell me the part I don’t know - how?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: For starters, you’ll need to infiltrate the Eclipse’s main base.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: That’s right. Fortunately for you, I’ve brought you round to the back way. It’s right through that crevice. Once you reach the base, you’ll see the objective: a derelict Tallneck that’s been extensively... modified. Climb the Tallneck Grafted into the top of its disc, you’ll find a... module of sorts. Destroy that and the Focus network will crash.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So you were part of the Eclipse.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: I’ve never been part of anything. I serve my own interests. Always. But... it is the case that I... assisted the Eclipse. Before I sensed the threat they might become. It was a mistake - that I’m doing what I can to correct.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What sort of assistance did you give them?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Head through the crevice, Aloy. You have more important things to do than ask questions.
[He goes offline. Aloy is stomping her foot in anger.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Let’s see what’s through here. Corrupted machines. Patrolling, like guards.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: More like soldiers, held in reserve for a war yet to come. You’ll have to get past them.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: This is the easy way in?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: The back way. I didn’t say it’d be easy.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Here we go again.
[She carefully sneaks in and destroys corrupted machines.]

Speaker: Sylens
Text: The Tallneck’s just over this ridge. You’ll see it when you reach the top. Now be ready to act fast. You need to get in and get it done before they raise an alarm. Here we go.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You getting this? I see the legs of a Tallneck down there, but... no Tallneck.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Damn. The transmitter’s been moved. Check down the ravine, to the left. Only place it could be.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So much for your “insider knowledge.” Towards the explosions? Great.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: You’ve got exactly one shot at this, Aloy, so spare the sarcasm and make it count. You see that bridge, over the ravine?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Yep.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Memorize its location. There’s a rappel point on the side. That’ll be your way out.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And these Eclipse Troopers?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Avoid them or kill them - your choice. The blasting should cover any noise you make. Find the Tallneck, and destroy the module on top.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Here we go.
[She jumps into cultist’s war camp.]

Speaker: Cultist Dredger
Text: Nice not to be working the pit tonight. All that grime.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’d have to leave something else behind. The Rappel point. It’ll get me out of here, but first I need to crash the network. That shelter - it’s bigger than the others.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Find the Tallneck, Aloy. There’s no time to poke around.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: There is if I make time. Is there fighting up ahead?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: No. It’s... a mining operation. So long as you’re quick, it won’t affect you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Oh, good, another secret…
[She finds a tent.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: This armor... There’s only one man big enough to wear this. Helis! This is his shelter? Not exactly fancy.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: What would you expect of a fanatic? His only extravagance is his brutality.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So you know him.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Just enough to want to stop him.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Wouldn’t have been easy to drag the Tallneck down this path. Why bother?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Just find it and get to the top. Destroy the module. And then get out, fast as you can.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Sure is a lot of blasting up there. Sounds busy.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Busy enough not to notice you, let’s hope.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I see it. They’ve built some kind of… structure around it.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Climb it. The sooner this is done, the better.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I don’t like this. It feels… wrong.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Everything here is wrong, Just get to the module and destroy it!
[She climbs to the head of Tallneck.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I see the module!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Good. Now be quick.
[She sees a giant spiral car. Apparently, the cultist is trying to free it with the help of explosions.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: This… this is Hades?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Aloy, this is not the time...

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It’s... a Metal Devil?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Open the module’s casing - now! Aloy! Do as I say, or all is lost!
[She tries to open the casing but it shocks her. Now Hades controls it.]

Speaker: HADES
Text: Entity... has come here? Entity... miscalculated. Entity... cannot destroy me. I am beyond its reach.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Maybe you are! But this isn’t!
[Pokes the casing with her spear.]

Speaker: HADES
Text: DESTROY THE ENTITY!
[Tallneck is being undermined by missiles. Aloy begins to run away from the base.]

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Keep running!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: This looks easy!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Keep moving!
[Tallneck is being shot with missiles. Aloy manages to avoid imminent death.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Yeah, you think? What do you think I’m doing, taking a nap? No way! Whoa! Almost there! Come on!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Keep moving! Run, don’t fight!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Head left - towards the camp!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Got it! Almost out of it!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: The whole base is on high alert.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Yeah, I noticed!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Keep moving, or you’ll die! Watch out! There’s more ahead!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Bridge in sight!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: That’s the way out!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I know!
[She rappels down but something explodes behind her. She’s being blasted by the wave and hitting the ground hard.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Ah! Aaaaaah!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Rough-going, but you survived.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You knew Hades was there, and you sent me to him?!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: I won’t deny I risked your life. But it was the only way. Now, with the focus network down, we can both get what we want - access to the secrets of Zero Dawn.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m past trusting you with secrets.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Good. That means you’re wising up. Trust is for fools. It shifts and crumbles like sand - a poor foundation for any partnership. But mutual self-interest - now that is a solid bedrock, upon which you and I might build a new science of understanding. We both need answers, Aloy. Thanks to you, we’re on the verge of grasping them. At Sunfall. We’ll speak again.
[He goes offline.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You miserable... damn him. If I could toss this Focus and be rid of you, Sylens, I would. But we both know I need it. Sunfall it is. And Zero Dawn.
[Aloy galloping to a settlement called Sunfall.]

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Sunfall. The Mad King Jiran’s summer palate. A bulwark of Carja might against the howling Forbidden West.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Thanks for the history lesson.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: But they have no idea what lies beneath. We will learn much from this, Aloy.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That’s what I’m hoping...
[She’s going to some kind of arena. Three soldiers armed with spears sluggishly fight with a Trumpler.]

Speaker: Sylens
Text: The Sun-Ring. A proud tradition of the Carja.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Stay off my Focus.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: If the Eclipse catches you here, you’ll be lucky if you survive long enough to wind up in that ring. Now we get to see if your attack on their Focus network was entirely successful.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What are you talking about?! Did I crash the network or not?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: In theory, all should be well. Success. Welcome to the Citadel, Aloy. I’ll check back with you in a moment. In the meantime – circulate.

Speaker: Shadow Carja Crier
Text: Outlanders! If you want to hear about today’s bounties head for the throne room! You’re not going to make any shards by standing out here!  Filthy mercenary bottom-feeders.

Speaker: Kam
Text: I hear the Shadow Cara are looking for one of their own. Should pay well.

Speaker: Shadow Carja Crier
Text: What are waiting around for, outlander? Bounties are announced inside!
[Aloy enters the Citadel.]

Speaker: Bahavas
Text: By the glory of the Sun revealed! Behold! Radiant Itamen, the one true Sun King, the light in shadow, whose will us light and whose light is law!
[Five years old child, that barely stands on his own feet, gets off his nurse’s knees.]

Speaker: Itamen
Text: I command Lucent Bahawas to speak on my behalf.

Speaker: Bahavas
Text: By the will of Radiant Itamen does the Sun glare down mercilessly upon the traitor Uthid! To the hunter who brings his head to us shall go a bounty of 500 Shards!
[Some black girl, dressed like Arabic princess approach Aloy.]

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: More prisoners than royalty, don’t you think? Hnn. Love your hair. You and I need to chat, little huntress. The green tent down in Shadowside. I’ll be waiting.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Uh, kinda busy.

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: We both know you’re no killer for hire. Uthid is innocent. So come see me - while there’s still time to save him.
[She leaves.]

Speaker: Sylens
Text: So... the “way in” I spoke of is right behind you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You’ve got to be kidding.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Not at all. And you needn’t worry about the Kestrels. They’ll be too busy acting important to pay attention to you.

Speaker: Odund
Text: First time in the Citadel, got to see the Sun-Ring from on high!

Speaker: Elkend
Text: But the Kestrels!

Speaker: Odund
Text: Ha! They want us to see this, boy! It makes quite an impression!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: This is insane.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Hardly.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: They’re going to see me.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: You underestimate the ease of hiding in plain sight. The balustrade. It’s a short drop from there. The other side of the tower. Look for a vent.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I see you’ve been here before.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Obviously. Now, it’s very important that you hear what I’m about to say. I’ve shown you the way in - but this humble vent marks a point of no return. Before you descend into the depths here, you should be fully committed, equipped, and focused. No distractions. If you have errands to run, do them first, or hold your peace. I won’t tolerate whining. Is that clear?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You’ll tolerate what I give you, Sylens. I didn’t ask you along for the ride.
[She decides to help Vanasha. She goes down to the lower town and finds Vanasha feeding poor children.]

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: The food is from Dowager Queen Nasadi, little ones. Her highness knows times are hard, and helps when she can. Eat, but bring some home for your families. If you have one.
[Aloy approaches.]

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: I’ve heard whispers about you -- rides machines, fancy spear, delightful freckles. Some even say you have a conscience. How extraordinary!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Who are you? You’re obviously not one of the Shadow Carja.

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: My name is Vanasha. For now, all you need to know is that I’m a whisper of reason in this howling pit of insanity.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Hmm. I know how that feels.

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: I’m sure you do. And so does Uthid. He’s a good man, so naturally the Shadow Carja want to murder him. I’ve done some digging, and I think he’s headed for the Greenclimb. It won’t take those mercenaries long to find him. He could use some help, if you’re so inclined.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Stop being evasive and tell me who you really are.

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Stop being evasive? You might as well tell me to stop being charming. It’s impossible. But I like you, so I’ll tell you a secret. I have friends in Meridian, and I like to do favors for them when I can. Uthid might be of use to them... if he survives.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: How do you know Uthid is innocent?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: I’m excellent at making inquiries. Look: he feeds orphans from his own rations and personally, punishes anyone who hurts the old or infirm. The idea that he would try to kill Itamen is ridiculous. He must have found something that can embarrass the priesthood. Otherwise, Bahavas wouldn’t risk marking such a well-regarded man for death.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What makes you think he’s on the Greenclimb?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: He knows he’ll be pursued, so he needs a hideout that’s both familiar and defensible, He once single-handedly held off an entire bandit clan in those foothills. My guess is that he’ll fall back on what worked before.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’ll do what I can for Uthid. But what about you?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: What about me, what?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What will you do while I risk my life?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Useful things, little huntress. Look for three dead trees south of Sunfall - they mark the start of the Greenclimb. Good luck!
[Aloy rides to the place.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Three dead trees, just like Vanasha said. Let’s see if Uhtid came through here. These tracks lead up that rise. Must be the Greenclimb. Foot tracks stop here. Time to climb. All right, made it. Where did you go, Uthid?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Food scraps. I’ll bet Uthid stopped to see if he was being followed. He must have kept going. I’ve got to catch up. A dead Machine Uthid’s been hunting. Everything useful has beer stripped. Uthid’s been gathering components, probably for armo. Uh-oh. Glinthawks, looking to scavenge.
[She deals with them.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Allright, back to Uthid. Where’d he go from here? Dead Watchers. More scrap for Uthid’s stockpile. Uthid took down a Ravager. Not an easy kill, but worth it for the parts.

[Climbing the mountain, she walks on a small bridge, when suddenly an arrow flies near her. She dodges it. А man dressed in something that looks like a 16th century Samurai armour, peeps from behind a stone.]

Speaker: Uthid
Text: The next one doesn’t miss.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Uthid?

Speaker: Uthid
Text: You’re young for a bounty hunter. Or I’m old for a soldier.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m not here for the price on your head, Uthid. I believe you’re innocent.

Speaker: Uthid
Text: Innocent! Come on, then. If this is a trick, it’s a good one. You’ve earned your kill.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Snow haze - white as bone Huh, that thought got dark.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: No tricks. Just talk.

Speaker: Uthid
Text: All right. Speak.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I want to know what happened at Sunfall. What really happened.

Speaker: Uthid
Text: All right. For weeks, each dawn in the tent city came with a new death. Always in their sleep, no struggle. The old, the infirm... sometimes the young. Those who couldn’t fight for the cause. I should have realized then it was a culling.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Who would do such a thing?

Speaker: Uthid
Text: They thought it was a curse, an evil spirit. But it was only a man, and a silent poison. It took time to catch him, but we did. We brought him before Bahavas, for the Sun’s judgment.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The High Priest Bahavas? He’s the one who put the bounty out on you.

Speaker: Uthid
Text: Yes. He thanked me for my diligence, and then had his guards release the villain. You see? It was he who ordered the culling! Then they turned on us. Should have died with my men, so their loyalty meant something. Twenty years I gave to the Sun, for what? Malice and murder. As for honor, sacrifice-- true sacrifice, the kind priests and rulers know nothing of -- it’s all a fat joke.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: If it’s honor you seek, the Sun Carja seem trustworthy. A little stuck up, maybe, but trustworthy.

Speaker: Uthid
Text: Those Carja once raided your Nora lands. Raided every land we could reach! It was the Sun’s will I did what I was told. Others did worse. But... as their captain...

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Uthid, I don’t care what you did-- I can’t absolve you. But the Carja are changing their ways. You could too.

Speaker: Uthid
Text: Perhaps. Avad doesn’t understand what the Sun demands of its soldiers.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Perhaps he understands it too well?

Speaker: Uthid
Text: Now you sound like the Blameless Marad.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I can believe you’re a good man. But why go with the Shadow Carja in the first place? Why serve them?

Speaker: Uthid
Text: Because of Itamen, of course. He was the One True Sun-King.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Itamen’s just a child.

Speaker: Uthid
Text: Yes - An untainted vessel! I believed he was pure. But they used him. Used our faith. I can see that now-- no shadows under a noonday sun. Bahavas didn’t need to disgrace my name. I did it myself, serving a rotten throne.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I met someone who wants to get you out of this. A woman named Vanasha. But first, we need to get out of here.

Speaker: Uthid
Text: What... are you? You look like a hunter, you give orders like a soldier who’s been out-- Mercenaries. Think they’ll all line up to tell me I’m innocent?

Speaker: Kikuk
Text: Should have stated on the coins, Carja! The mountains belong to us. Kikuk’s Killers! When we’re done with you, you won’t even leave an echo!

Speaker: Uthid
Text: Not much gets by you.
[Archery battle begins.]

Speaker: Kikuk’s Killers Outlander
Text: Move in! We’ll send in the rest as soon as they arrive! It’s up to you now, men. Rally! We can still finish them. Keep up the attack! We’ve still got another squad on the way!

Speaker: Uthid
Text: That won’t be the last of them. Follow me - I’ve stashed supplies up above. Up and over! Grab what you can while we still have time.
[Unexpectedly, three Oseram warriors approach them from above.]

Speaker: Odund
Text: A robust defense is the most satisfying to break! All right, Marvels. We brought the priest out here, so let’s put on a show for him.

Speaker: Uthid
Text: I know that hood. We’ve unfinished business, Bahavas and I. This will be difficult think you rallied to a lost cause.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I don’t intend to die today, Uthid.

Speaker: Uthid
Text: I did. But you’re starting to change my mind.
[They fight and win.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That’s the last of the Marvels!

Speaker: Uthid
Text: Bahavas thought he has enough fodder to keep him sale. Now there’s hope for justice. Will you come with me? This won’t be easy. Bahavas still has his personal guard. Across there, and we’ll have him!
[They climb the mountain.]

Speaker: Bahavas
Text: I had to come here myself! To end you suffering, Uthid-- and mine. The outlanders led us here. And now that they are dead, their price is most affordable. But enough with needles. It’s time for blades. Remove them from the Sun’s sight. Kill the traitor! Kill the Nora! The sun sets on your pathetic life, Uthid.
[Aloy and Uthid kills his guards.]

Speaker: Bahavas
Text: Wherever deal you worked out with him - I’ll double it! More than double it.

Speaker: Uthid
Text: No. I’m tired of this, Bahavas. The lies and the violence and your cheap scented oils... I don’t suppose you’d kill yourself?

Speaker: Bahavas
Text: I had to-- I had to! Prune the weak, or all the Carja in Shadow are doomed!

Speaker: Uthid
Text: This solves nothing. But may the Sun find some worth among your drying bones.

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: That was quite a firework show!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You took your time.

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: I was busy. What do you think happened to Yun’s Shunred, the other mercenary band? And I had to organize passage to Meridian for a wanted man. Give us a moment, Uthid. Girl talk. You’ve had quite a day. I never imagined Bahavas would blunder into his own trap. His death opens up wonderful possibilities. Remember Itamen and Nasadi, the child-king and his mother, guarded like hostages at Sunfall? With Bahavas gone no one will be watching them. I want to get them out, and I could use your help.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Kidnapping the Sun-King of the Shadow Carja is no small task.

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: It’s not kidnapping. They want to go to Meridian, to safety.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: How do you know that?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: I’ve been posing as Nasadi’s handmaiden. She’s scared. For herself, of course, but mostly for Itamen.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What’s going to happen to Uthid now?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Don’t worry! You gave him a second life, and I’ll put it to good use. He’ll be welcomed in Meridian as a military advisor. Hopefully he can help Avad finish the Shadow Carja with as little bloodshed as possible.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What’s going to happen at Sunfall now that Bahavas is dead?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Oh, it will be glorious. The priests will panic. There’ll be infighting, skullduggery, and backstabbing as they wrangle for power. Best of all, they’ll be distracted. Bahavas! Your life brought misery, but your death is a flower that blooms in abundance.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why do you care what happens to them?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Itamen is the Shadow Carja’s figurehead. If he defects, it will remove their last trace of legitimacy. Beyond that he’s just a boy who clings to his mommy. He made a little Grazer for me out of matchsticks once. It wasn’t very good, but still. Nobody ever made anything for me before.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What do you need to get Nasadi and Itamen out of Sunfall?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: With Bahavas dead, Sunfall is the easy part - I’ll handle that. The big fuss will be crossing the border to the Sundom. Find my friend Three-toe Huadiv near the Branded Shore. I hired his crew to sweep the path, so all you have to do is wait for me.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: If this Huadiv has already cleared the area, why do you need me?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Contingencies, little huntress. Something will go wrong, and I need protection I can count on - you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’ll try not to disappoint.
[Traitor’s Bounty completed.]

Speaker: Uthid
Text: The Nora said you would help me. Are we bound for Meridian?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Only if you want to go, my dear.

Speaker: Uthid
Text: What choice do I have?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: None at all. I was just being polite.

Speaker: Uthid
Text: What makes you think Avad will welcome me, after I served his enemies?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: He’s a forgiving man. Just smile a lot. You can smile, can’t you? ...No, that’s a grimace. Nervous about going to Meridian?

Speaker: Uthid
Text: I’ve been a soldier for twenty years. I do not get nervous.

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Not even around a pretty lady?

Speaker: Uthid
Text: I will not dignify that with a response.

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: I think I’ll take a moment with Bahavas. Death suits him better than those robes ever did. Remember - Look for Three-Toe Huadiv near the Branded Shore.
[Aloy goes looking for the man.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You’re Three-Toe Huadiv, right? Vanasha sent me. What happened?

Speaker: Three-Toed Huadiv
Text: I got hornswoggled, that’s what. Vanasha batted her lashes, wiggled her hips, and promised us treasure. Clear a path for the royals, she said - sneak past the garrison and skewer a few Watchers. Hardly a bother! Little did we know there was a damned monstrosity lurking underground! When will I learn not to gawk at skinny girls?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why do you think Vanasha swindled you?

Speaker: Three-Toed Huadiv
Text: My crew came to Sunfall because we heard the bounties were fat. She offered us the fattest one of all, enough to retire on. It’s my own damned fault for taking the bait. Should have known I’d end up with a rupture in my useful parts.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So Vanasha needed safe passage for Nasadi and Itamen, but it didn’t work out?

Speaker: Three-Toed Huadiv
Text: She made it sound so sweet and easy. Find the best path to the lake, make sure it’s safe. What could go wrong? Turns out, a lot. Like bloody murder in the grinding jaws of a heinous death-beast!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Something attacked you from underground?

Speaker: Three-Toed Huadiv
Text: Oh, you picked that up, did you? I wondered why the Shadow Carja didn’t pay attention to the pass. Well, they don’t need to. A rock-eating demon guards it for ’em! It tunnels in the dirt, breaks through the earth, and blasts rocks from its stinking face!!! I barely escaped. My comrades weren’t so lucky. I might shed a tear, if they weren’t all cutthroats and cheaters.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Vanasha will be here soon with Nasadi and Itamen. I’ve got to destroy that thing in the pass before they arrive.

Speaker: Three-Toed Huadiv
Text: You’re not too bright, are you? Well, we didn’t last long against it, but I’ll tell you what I know. It has armor everywhere, a little less at the rear. And when it goes underground, it’ll lose track of you if you’re quiet. You might even be able to keep it from going under altogether if you hit its big crooked arms hard enough. That’s all I can offer, friend. I promise to look solemn at your funeral before I hit the bar.
[Aloy destroys the machine.]

Speaker: Three-Toed Huadiv
Text: By the radiant Sun. I can’t believe it! I thought that evil rock-chewer would grind you up! After that miracle, all we can do is wait. Vanasha will be here soon, along with a boat that’ll take the royals across the lake.
[They sits at a campfire and wait til sunset.]

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Ah, little huntress -- glad you accepted my invitation to play bodyguard. Where are your men, Huadiv? It looks like something chewed you up and spat you out.

Speaker: Three-Toed Huadiv
Text: That’s pretty much exactly what happened.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The way is clear. Can we go?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: I like how you always cut to the chase - in this case, literally. It won’t be long before we’re followed.  Don’t be afraid, your radiance. We’ve got excellent protection.

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Oh dear. Here come the Shadow Carja. And they’re very angry with me.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’ll hold them off.

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Very noble of you, but when I start a fuss, I like to finish it. Not that your assistance isn’t welcome. Huadiv! Get Itamen and his mother to the shore. Carefully! So it comes to this. I must say - after two years under the heel of these zealots, I’m ready to extract a little blood. Some traps would be nice. Shall we prepare a little surprise for them? Are you sure don’t have any traps, little huntress? Take cover up there, behind that rock. Here they are. Let’s make it hurt, shall we? More of the bastards. Get ready.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And... done.

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Well now. Seems I worked up a bit of a sweat. I don’t want to jinx it, but we might be in the clear.
[Two Carja warriors approach.]

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: A bit late, aren’t we, gentlemen?

Speaker: Carja Archer
Text: Sorry ma’am. The boat’s waiting.
[Some dinosaur like roar is heard.]

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Damn, I spoke too soon.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: This one’s mine. Get to the boat.

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: You know, this time I think I might be out of my league.  If anything happens to her, I will be very cross.

Speaker: Carja Spearman
Text: We’re not going anywhere.
[Aloy and the warriors destroys Corrupted Thunderjaw, after which she runs to the boat.]

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Not exactly a royal barge, is it? Oh well. Defectors can’t be choosers. Let’s get aboard, shall we?
[They set sail.]

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: You’ve done a good thing - maybe even ended a war.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Maybe. But my war just keeps going.
[They come to Meridian. At the quayside they are met by Avad with his entourage.]

Speaker: Avad
Text: Itamen, my brother. Welcome home. You have nothing to fear -- you are now under the protection of the Sundom. My protection. As is your mother. She will not be harmed. You have my word, the law of the Sun. Aloy - it seems I see your influence everywhere. You have done so much for the Sundom and it will always be appreciated. You have my thanks. May you walk in the light.

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Appalling. I spend two years in the forbidden west setting this up, and the redhead gets all the credit.

Speaker: Three-Toed Huadiv
Text: I’m still getting paid, right?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: You’ll be lucky if I let you live. I couldn’t have done this without you. When we meet again, I’ll give you a proper thanks, promise.
[Aloy goes back to Sunfall and pry open the door to some shed.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m heading down.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: I’ve spent a lifetime trying to uncover the secrets of this world. Where the machines came from. How the Old Ones achieved such marvels, only to fall into silence and death. A lifetime of failure, as year by year, decade after decade. I hit walls I could not break, doors I could never breach.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Hello.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Until a Nora huntress marched out of the Savage East and... voila! For her, all the deepest secrets of the Earth were laid bare. I suspect you’ll have an easier time with this door than I did years ago.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Hold for identiscan. Genetic profile confirmed. Entry authorized. Malfunction... Malfunction... Malfunction... Malfunction....

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Are you kidding me?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: You don’t hear me laughing.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Shut up! There’s got to be a way... Hey! Elisabet Sobeck here, requesting access!

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Access request acknowledged. Root command functions available. Do you wish to proceed?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I do! Get me through this door!

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Analyzing… Primary access inoperable due to mechanical failure. Emergency venting procedure - likely to circumvent blockage. Do you wish to proceed?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Yes!

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Emergency venting, authorized.
[After all the systems have been vented, the door begins to open slowly.]

Speaker: Sylens
Text: I underestimated you. You’d think by now -
[Two Carja guards notice that the ducts, which have been out of operation for thousands of years begin to work...]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Guess you can’t have everything.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: That will draw attention. We won’t have this place to ourselves for a long now.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: We? Last I checked, I was the one risking my life down here.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Yes, fine. Now will you please get moving? There’s so much to learn and less time than I’d hoped.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Welcome to Project: Zero Dawn.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Zero Dawn! We found it!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Are you really so surprised?

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Facility diagnostics detect multiple failures. Attempting repair.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So what was this room?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: An entrance hall, perhaps? Have a look around.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Please take a seat and wait for your name to be called. A selection of beverages and snacks are available.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: A smaller room...

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Please proceed into Viewing Room 1 for an important message regarding the purpose of your visit.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What was this place?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: A holographic theater.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: ZD_0_1 data intact. Initiating playback.

Speaker: Herres
Text: Welcome to Project: Zero Dawn. I’m General Herres, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff of the United States of America. I’m sure you’ve heard the rumors. That Zero Dawn is a top-secret superweapons program. The technological miracle that will save us from the Faro Plague - if Operation: Enduring Victory can hold off the robots long enough. The reason I’m sure you’ve heard the rumors is that I’m the one who spread them. And they are all lies. Zero Dawn is not a superweapons program and I will not save us. Nothing will save us, and here’s why. By the time the Glitch was noticed, it was already too late. Nothing could stop the Faro Plague. Nothing can. Its robots will continue to replicate and devour the biosphere. Life on Earth will be destroyed... our planet reduced to a barren sphere. Global extinction is inevitable. No matter how many we kill, the robots just keep exponentially making more. If we had their deactivation codes, we could shut them all down. The entire swarm. But since their cryptographic protocols use poly-phasic entangled waveforms, cracking a code set would take half a century. At best, we’ve got 16 months. Not exactly what you’d call a survival option. The destruction of a biosphere is not the sort of apocalypse you can wait out in a fallout shelter or space station. There will be no Earth left to reclaim. Just a lifeless, toxic rock with several million Faro robots on it... hibernating, waiting for something to eat. This is the horrible truth behind the lies of Operation: Enduring Victory - my lies - lies designed to inspire millions of innocents to sacrifice themselves in battle. Why? One reason: to buy time for you and the work you will do here. Zero Day - the day that life on Earth ceases to exist - is coming fast. It cannot be stopped. The hope of Zero Dawn is that something new might come after. But I will leave it to Elisabet Sobeck to shine that thin ray of light into the darkness, Herres out.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That doesn’t make sense! Life on earth didn’t cease to exist!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: He said it could not be stopped.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But it was! Somehow Elisabet saved us! I’ve got to keep looking, find out how she did it... Kestrels! They got in - through the vents!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Let nothing stop you from learning the truth.

Speaker: Shadow Heavy
Text: Spread out! If it moves, kill it!

Speaker: Shadow Soldier
Text: What is this place? A tomb?
[Aloy quietly kills them.]

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Good. We’re too close to let tribal primitives stop us now. The data points. What do they contain?
[Aloy scans an interview with Susanne Alpert]

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: with Susanne Alpert, environmental scientist. Doctor?

Speaker: DR. ALPERT
Text: I’m sorry? I wasn’t--

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: Just stating your name. What were you thinking about, Doctor?

Speaker: DR.ALPERT
Text: Nothing the General said. Not really. I was on the Syzygy/East response team in 2051. Just after the second earthquake compromised the reactor. I still dream about it, after these years. The Red Zone spreading on the imaging, slowly so slowly, like a hand opening its fingers.

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: Your involvement in that event is why you were asked for by name.

Speaker: DR. ALPERT
Text: Really? That’s interesting. Because. nothing worked. Nothing could grow there again. It was a catastrophic failure. But the Red Zone is a blip compared to global-scale biomass biosphere and hydrosphere will collapse, render the Earth uninhabitable, long before the robots finish us. Enduring Victory can’t buy time against that... So you’d better show me what Zero Dawn really is.
[Aloy scans Counselor Guidelines]
[Aloy scans an interview with Cpt. Okilo.]

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: I’m sure you now understand the urgency of why we brought you here, Ms. Okilo.

Speaker: CAPTAIN OKILO
Text: Captain Okilo. Are you trying to thank me for not resisting?

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: I believe we couldn’t negotiate a diplomatic solution.

Speaker: CAPTAIN OKILO
Text: When it came to my country’s lithium, it was always a swarm that would be sent to negotiate. Metallurgic International. US Robot Command... The markings changed, but the robots were the same.

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: You have had considerable experience in human-robot conflict.

Speaker: CAPTAIN OKILO
Text: Yes, and I’ve got the prosthetic limbs to show it. Still I continued to face this horror, even though the challenge was great. Cyber-warfare. I thought Zero Dawn would be a... a “Manhattan Project”, to generate the deactivation codes. With the resources I had, I estimated code-breaking to be a hopeless endeavor. I almost looking forward to being proved wrong.

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: Unfortunately your estimation was correct.

Speaker: CAPTAIN OKILO
Text: As your General Herres said. So then. You did not bring me here to commiserate. What is left?
[Aloy scans an interview with Ron Felder.]

Speaker: RON FELDER
Text: Look. Let’s cut the mystery, you’re building a colony ship. It’s obvious. And it’s not going to fly. I mean, literally. Remember the Odyssey that multi-national heap of space junk that’s been in graveyard orbit since ’57? That went nowhere, real slow, and you have to get somewhere real fast. Do you have any idea the immensity of the challenge, to prep a new colony ship in time?

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: To be clear, I’m not a worker on the project-

Speaker: RON FELDER
Text: Do - do you even understand how few people it could even save? The whole generation-ship concept is, is not going to happen! It’s the first thing you’d abandon in favor of embryonics. For that kind of storage we’re talking a lot of bulk, a lot of power, a lot of resources so even if you do it, even if you build it and point it at Sirius X, there’s no room for people on that thing, all right!?

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: If you could try to remain calm-

Speaker: RON FELDER
Text: You people are crazy if you think you’re getting off this rock! No-one’s getting off!

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: Medical!
[Aloy scans an interview with Tom Paech.]

Speaker: TOM PAECH
Text: So these mechanical monstrosities, they don’t just kill people, they feed off them?

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: Not just people. All organic matter.

Speaker: TOM PAECH
Text: Every living thing dissolved into nutrients? Millennia of evolution liquefied?! The miracle of life reduced to -bloody bio-fuel?!

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: In a word? Yes.

Speaker: TOM PAECH
Text: Who did this? Faro? That arsehole! Is he here?

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: No. Doctor! Please...

Speaker: TOM PAECH
Text: Tell him Tom Paech wants a word! (sounds of struggle]

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: Doctor! Please!

Speaker: TOM PAECH
Text: YOU GET TED FARO IN HERE!
[Aloy scans an interview with Travis Tate.]

Speaker: TRAVIS TATE
Text: Hoo! So mama, she was right!

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: Pardon?

Speaker: TRAVIS TATE
Text: My mother, she took her Bible real serious. Not just Texas Bubble serious. Pentecostal serious. Favorite chapter? Revelations. Now. I didn’t always understand her on account of all that speaking in tongues and such but when she did use her words, it was always End Times - this and Lake of Fire-that, on account of sinful lifestyles. Speaking which mind if I smoke?

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: A... tobacco cigarette?

Speaker: TRAVIS TATE
Text: Sorry, darling, my tastes run classic. Compliments to your team, tracked me down. Been a price on my head 18 months now. Sterling-Malkeet was me, of course, don’t mind admitting. Been plenty of snakesters chasing the bounty, too, but I kept the zigging to their zag. How’d you finger me?

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: I believe Dr. Sobeck listed you as an Alpha candidate. Priority snatch-and-grab.

Speaker: TRAVIS TATE
Text: Always suspected she had a little thing for me. Hey - don’t supposed you got real coffee in this place? You know blood coffee? Conflict cappuccinos?

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: Mr. Tate, I’m clearing you to proceed. Just…
[Aloy scans an interview with Brad Andac.]

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: ...previously worked for Faro Automated Systems.

Speaker: BRAD ANDAC
Text: On the Chariot line self-replication routines. I came here thinking this was a rendition. When your people took me, I thought, “About time.” I’ve been trying to swallow the guilt every day since... since, ah...

Speaker: COUNSELOR
Text: Would you like to take a moment?

Speaker: BRAD ANDAC
Text: No, no - I just... really hoped Zero Dawn was a way to undo it all. My work. I’m sorry to say I was ever proud of it. But Ted could really sell a concept, and in the labs, in the... light of creation... That first test run, when you saw they understood their own structures, could rebuild themselves from memory and light… There were no limits. Oh, God, there were no limits.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: ZD_0_2 data intact. Initiating playback.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Elisabet Sobeck!

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: You’ve heard the bad news, and it’s all true. The Faro Plague is devouring the biosphere. But does that have to be the end? What if we could give life - a future? What if we could build a kind of seed, from which, on a dead planet, life could blossom anew? This is the aim - the hope - of Project: Zero Dawn: to create a super intelligent fully-automated... terraforming system - And bring life back from lifelessness. What would such a system require? At its core, it would need a true AI. Fully capable of making the trillions of decisions necessary to reconstitute the biosphere. An immortal guardian, devoted to the re-flourishing of life. We call it GAIA. Mother Nature as an AI. But that’s just the core of the system. She will need to be surrounded and empowered by a comprehensive suite of Subordinate Functions. Think of them as extensions of GAIA’s mind, each dedicated to a specific purpose. Now these aren’t Als, but make no mistake - each presents an engineering challenge more profound… than anything the human species has ever before attempted. Hardware that preserves adengestates the billions of seeds and embryos from which life will be reborn. The construction of underground facilities to hold it all. And that’s just the start. We don’t have to build the entire system. The beauty of a fully automated terraforming system is that it can build itself. Now, over the days to come, you’ll learn how all these Functions - all these pieces that you’ll be working on - fit together. How we’ll race the clock to execute our harvest initiatives, write the software, build the tech and the facilities! How we’ll lock it down and seal it up before the inevitable occurs. But even more important, you’ll know how it doesn’t end here. How GAIA will generate these deactivation codes General Herres talked about... and build the transmission arrays to broadcast them, shutting down the Faro robots for good. How GAIA will not just build but imagine any conceivable robot it needs to do its work across centuries.... from detoxifying the Earth’s ravaged atmosphere and poisoned seas... to the re-greening of the Earth from cryo-preserved seed stocks... to re-wilding the Earth with animal life. And then, when all that is done, how a new generation of human beings, spawned at Cradle facilities around the globe… will partake of APOLLO: the vast archive of human knowledge and cultural achievement from which they will learn of us, our world, and most important how not to repeal our mistakes. It’s not an impossible dream. It is within our grasp if we work tirelessly and stop at nothing to achieve it. We can’t stop life from ending. But if you will help me help GAIA - we can give it a future. Join me, and help make that future real.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So... the whole Earth, destroyed... but then, remade?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Yes. By a machine. A machine of creation...

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Elisabet did this. For life. For us. But - why HADES, then? If it was part of GAIA, how’d it end up in the wreckage of a Faro robot? And why’s it want to kill me? And APOLLO - the archive of knowledge - what happened to that?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: I’m as confused as you are. Maybe the answers lie ahead.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Alert. Medical wing inaccessible.

Speaker: Shadow Heavy
Text: Intruder! Get her!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: They know I’m here now!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Whatever you do, don’t die now.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Power’s down.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Is there another route?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’ve done this before. Just need my Focus. Here we go. There’s a part missing. Maybe there’s a storage area nearby...? Done. I should check the door nearby.

Speaker: Maintenance Tech
Text: Hey, I’m done with Brett’s incompetence, okay? Somehow he managed to install an H-emitter node backwards. Everything’s in reverse. I don’t get paid to clean up Brett’s messes. If you want it fixed, send him up to storage for a new emitter, not me. Parker out.
[Aloy solve the puzzle and opens the door.]

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Now to see what lies beyond it.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Eclipse! They’re here!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Avoid contact.

Speaker: Cultist Punisher
Text: Lines look good!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: GAIA! It’s up there - second floor.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Can you reach it?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So much for avoiding contact.
[She kills the cultists.]

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Alert. Area inaccessible. Elevators non-operational. Stairwells have collapsed.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Phew. That’s the last of them.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Alert. H-Lock structural failure. Repeat: H-Lock structural failure.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Or not! Room’s clear. For a moment, anyway.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Then get moving. You have to find GAIA.

Speaker: Margo Shěn
Text: Hello! I’m Margo Shěn, and this is HEPHAESTUS! As the name might tip you off, this is going to be the subordinate function that GAIA will use to make lots and lots of robots. Her personal forge... except it’s not that simple. Um. So, like, you probably noticed that only about a third of you are robotics engineers. The rest, experts in machine cognition, virtual heuristics, that stuff. Well, that’s because we aren’t going to be the ones designing and building robots. The last thing we want is to burden GAIA with a bunch of outmoded twenty-first century designs. Waste of time! Our purpose is to empower GAIA to build the robots. And not just build - imagine - from scratch! Any robot she needs, for any conceivable purpose, designed and fabricated at a snap of a finger. Hers. Her finger. So HEPHAESTUS isn’t really the force It’s more like the knowledge of craft and ingenuity of a master smith, to wield the hammer. Encoded as software. Virtual creativity made real. GAIA’s already learning. In simulations, she’s doing some very creative things with fractal assembly and animal morphologies. Her designs aren’t about to win the Li-Em prize anytime soon, but hey, everyone has to start somewhere! So... Yes. Time to get started. Let’s do this.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I don’t get it.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Which part? It’s a little technical, in places -

Speaker: Aloy
Text: If GAIA was designed to save life, why would the robots it makes attack people?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Perhaps it loves some forms of life more than others.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The Derangement. The machines weren’t always so angry...

Speaker: Sylens
Text: True. Mostly they were docile, until ten, fifteen years ago.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: For years “Hephaestus” has been forcing Cauldrons to make aggressive machines. I’ve seen it myself. In the Cauldrons. Stalkers. Ravagers. A Thunderjaw. How could it do that? And why?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Why, indeed.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I think this is it! Elisabet Sobeck’s office! But it’s sealed off. There’s got to be a way inside...

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Keep looking.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: More Eclipse.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Careful, now...

Speaker: Samina Ebadji
Text: Welcome to APOLLO - the collective memory of the human species, and the wellspring of knowledge for future generations. I am Samina Ebadji. Until recently, I was Director of the International Collective Memory Institute in New Tehran. As a heritage professional, I devoted my career to the preservation of human knowledge, creative endeavor, and cultural achievement. APOLLO is, therefore, the ultimate embodiment of lifelong passion - albeit, under the very worst circumstances imaginable. The challenges before us are immense. Specifically, we will have to design and implement four major initiatives simultaneously. First: the construction of data repositories in Cradle facilities around the world, ensuring redundancy. Second: The collection and processing of a projected 180 million discrete data-entries.... - forty-two zettabytes of data - in Mandarin, English, Spanish and Arabic. Third: the transferal and encoding of all that data into DNA encapsulated in synthetic fossils, the only medium capacitors and durable enough to safeguard it without degradation for the centuries to come. And last but not least: The development of the holographic interface and gamified curricula… by which future humans will commune with APOLLO, progressively unlocking heuristic learning modules… “leveling up the knowledge and skills they will need to take control of the terraforming system. That is the future towards which all of our efforts will be directed. Notjust the preservation of the past… but the seed for the flourishing of a new tree of knowledge. Welcome. And let us begin.
[Aloy quietly kills some more cultists in the next room.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That’s the last of them. Alone once more.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: In what should have been a cave of wonders. Look around. See if anything is left.
[Aloy scans a datapont named Herres Testimonial.]

Speaker: GENERAL HERRES
Text: Dr. Sobeck, please archive this testimonial in APOLLO, cross-referenced to all mentions of my name and Operation: Enduring Victory. My name is General Aaron Herres. From 2060 to 2066. I served as the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the highest-ranked officer of the United States Armed Forces. The tenure of my command included strategic planning and oversight of Operation: Enduring Victory, a falsehood perpetrated on the civilian populations of the United States and other nations during the last 14 months of life on this planet. Before the Faro Plague, I did my job and did it well. I was bold and decisive, crafty in political maneuvers. It wasn’t an accident that I rose to my position and became the commander of the largest mechanized force ever assembled. But to what end? My only lasting achievement was the extinction of life on Earth. And my one redeeming act - if any - was to delay that extinction by days or week by throwing more death at it. It is my hope that there will be no need for men like me in the world to come. If you are one of the péople of that future world, listening to this message please know that I am sorry, and that I wish you well. Sincerely, General Aaron Herres.

Speaker: Travis Tate
Text: Welcome to HADES - Zero Dawn’s “extinction failsafe protocol” - the ultimate killer app! Now I know what you’re thinking. The purpose of GAIA is to resurrect life. So why give her a subordinate function, only purpose of which is to wipe life out all over again? I mean - what the what?! Just plumb crazy, ain’t it? Well no, it isn’t. Reconstituting a biosphere?
