That’s a tall order. Tack-smart as GAIA may be, odds are she won’t get it right the first time. I mean, imagine you’re GAIA, two hundred years from now, and this new biosphere you’re growing, it’s all gone wrong. Alkalines are skyrocketing, coniferous forests eroding under the lash of super-storms that would’ve drowned Noah. It’s chaos, a spinnin’ top that won’t stop wobbling. Now, what you gonna do? Release phase 1 organisms into that hot mess? Hope their CO2 and methane can balance out what you got started? Hell no. What you’re going to do, GAIA, is step aside while HADES takes over and does what you’re just too darn nurturing and life-loving to do. Which is burn that misbegotten mess of a biosphere to the ground so GAIA can start over. Okay, not burn. More like terraforming operations and suffocate it. But you get the idea. HADES takes the biosphere back to zero, square one, blank slate. And then, only then, does it hand the steering wheel back to GAIA and say: “try again, ol’ girl - and better this time, or we’ll have to do this again.” That’s HADES. It’s pretty badass when you think about it. Extinction on demand, death on speed dial. All for the greater good, of course, but still - kinda metal! So - welcome to HADES. Welcome to the void!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Okay... so if that’s the original purpose of HADES, why does it want me extinct?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: We need more data.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And how’s it end up in the wreckage of a Faro Titan, getting worshiped by the Eclipse like some kind of god?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: I’m learning as you are, Aloy. Keep searching.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Looks like the only way onwards.

Speaker: Patrick Brochard-Klein
Text: Welcome to ELEUTHIA, the crown and king of GAIA’s subordinate functions, for it is by ELEUTHIA that the human race will continue to exist. I am Patrick Brochard-Klein, the Alpha in charge of this program. Let one thing be perfectly clear from the outset. ELEUTHIA is not a genetic engineering project. Our goal is to preserve the human genome, not alter it. A snapshot of human genetic diversity, literally frozen in time - the genetic quintessence of our species, unmodified. Under my watch, our activities and initiatives will comply with the 2034 Clone Provisions and the 2048 Raleigh Accords. Now, that may seem a quaint, even trivial concern to you, in light of present circumstances - but... was one of the authors of the Accords, it is far from trivial to me. The practical challenges before us are... staggering in scope and complexity. But not insurmountable. Global collation and provisional storage of zygotes: perfection of exogenic technologies, design and perfection of servitors… to provide nurture and inculcation during early child development; all of these program components must and will proceed… in tandem - to say nothing of the breakneck construction of Cradle facilities at sites around the world. So... let us begin.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Are these... what I think they are?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Artificial wombs. Machines to spawn a new generation of human beings.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: “Cradle facilities.” Elisabet said a new generation of humans would be spawned inside such places.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: She did.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: All-Mother mountain - it was one of them?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: There’s only one way to be sure.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The hatch wouldn’t open. Something... Something about a corrupted Alpha Registry. I need to search Elisabet’s office.
[She scans GAIA’s log from 27 March 2065.]

Speaker: GAIA
Text: - would benefit from Antelopinae morphologies, though caprid forms show superior load bearing capability.

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: You’re a quick study, GAIA.

Speaker: GAIA
Text: Dr. Sobeck, as I have conducted this comparative analysis of mammalian morphologies. I have gathered extensive data on the Quaternary Extinction Event.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Looks like it used to hold something... some component that got removed.

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: Oh? And your assessment? GAIA?

Speaker: GAIA
Text: Logically speaking, the extinction was a natural consequence.

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: And yet?

Speaker: GAIA
Text: And yet... I find the loss of megafaunal species… unaccountably sad. That they passed forever into oblivion... causes me to experience a... grief... that is difficult to describe. Am I malfunctioning?

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: No, no, GAIA you are not. This is good. It’s very good.
[Aloy scans GAIA’s log from 13 January 2066.]

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: You will undergo a brief period of unconsciousness... during relocation to Prime and final instatement.

Speaker: GAIA
Text: Elisabet, may I speak outside protocol?

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: When you’re back up and running at the new site we’ll bring the subordinate functions online and see where we stand.

Speaker: GAIA
Text: Elisabet, I detect… distress. Are you all right?

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: I’m fine.

Speaker: GAIA
Text: I realize that circumstances compel us to launch earlier that we hoped, but all sub-systems are operational. The odds stand in our favor.

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: But what if - ? GAIA… there’s nothing left out there… you can’t even survive unless you’re wearing an environmental suit. There are billions dead… in fear and agony. What if… What if it was all for nothing...?

Speaker: GAIA
Text: Elisabet, extinction was inevitable. Thanks to you, life will have a future.

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: You really believe that?

Speaker: GAIA
Text: I believe in you, Elisabet. In you, all th - (the holorecord interrupts]
[Aloy pry opens the door to Elisabet’s office.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The Alpha Registry master file!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Intact?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Yes. No signs of corruption.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Then what are you waiting for? Copy the file!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: With this, I can restore the registry at the hatch inside All-Mother. Open it, go inside.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: And grasp the secrets within...

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Where I was bom. Maybe... maybe who gave birth to me...

Speaker: Sylens
Text: “Who”?! Are you really so naïve? There will be no “who” waiting for you there, Aloy. Whatever birthed you into the world was a “what,” not a “who.”

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You bastard.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Oh no, I had a legitimate birth. It’s you, Aloy, who are the creation of a machine. But what kind of machine - and why? Why were you created?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Eclipse.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: You need to get out of there. What you found is too valuable. You’re too valuable.
[While Aloy’s copying the file, Helis is repelling down into the facility. He throws a grenade at the office window. Aloy knocks out by explosion.]

Speaker: Helis
Text: Still alive. Good. I have a more suitable death in mind for you... child.
[She wakes up in a Sun-Ring’s cage.]

Speaker: Helis
Text: My entire life, I’ve always known one thing with prophetic certainty that I was destined for glory as a great champion of the Sun. Even when Jiran was murdered, even when Meridian fell, I never doubted my destiny… until you came along. When I heard that you had. survived... a doubt took root in my mind. As sure as the sun rises and falls each day, those I am bade to kill, die. And yet I failed. How? Why? With each dig site you attacked, each loyal soldier you killed… this pestering doubt grew… It grew when High Priest Bahavas went missing... and when the true Sun King, Itamen, was snatched away, it not only grew, but multiplied. I kept thinking of the moment my knife pierced your throat. One twist, a simple tug of the blade, and you would’ve bled out. In slaughter, I am a practiced hand. So why hesitate? Why fail my destined purpose?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: See that scar on your cheek? You didn’t get to finish.

Speaker: Helis
Text: Yes, I remember. He fought well… for a savage.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: His name was Rost, and he was a better man than you could ever hope to be!

Speaker: Helis
Text: The better man is the one who doesn’t end up with his guts steaming on the ground. No. It wasn’t him. I could have finished you before he attacked. But I didn’t. This failing... troubled my thoughts, haunted every step... It was only when I captured you down in that place. That I finally glimpsed the Sun’s design etched at length across the course of events. You were meant to survive that day on the mountain, meant to interfere at dig sites and kill my men... Meant to eliminate High Priest Bahavas… Meant to snatch Itamen away... Conversely, I was meant to capture you. Here so that you might die as a sacrificial offering to the Sun. Everything as it was meant to be. Predestined, and preordained.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Some destiny. You’re following orders, not some grand cosmic design. You’re a puppet, with Hades yanking the strings. A pawn, pushed around by larger forces. It’d be laughable if there weren’t so much killing involved. Hades is an ancient machine, not the Buried Shadow of Carja myth. It doesn’t care about Meridian. It wants to kill everything and everyone - and you are its dutiful slave.

Speaker: Helis
Text: I serve not the Buried Shadow, but the Sun in shadow. All halves of nature joined to one cause, Shadow to Sun, Dark to Light.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Do you really not hear how ridiculous that sounds? You’ve gone from serving an insane, homicidal Sun King to an insane, homicidal machine. You’re moving down in the world, not up!

Speaker: Helis
Text: I’ll remember those words as I watch your corpse burn, Whatever’s left of it. You fail to grasp the point. As surely as you’ve been conquered, so has all doubt. And with certainty of belief comes unstoppable force.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Then open this cage and put your faith to the test. See if things work out like you expect.

Speaker: Helis
Text: The circle has closed. Every element is in its proper place - exactly where it belongs. The errant beast, now caged, will serve her true purpose. A sacrificial animal. Ah... speaking of sacrifice... I forgot to tell you. After you crashed the Eclipse network, I sent messengers into the east. To rally the forces there and mount an invasion of the “Sacred Land.” I ordered every Nora killed, I was hoping to catch you there, but alas, it all seems to have been unnecessary.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why butcher dozens of innocents for no gain? It’s a waste of effort.

Speaker: Helis
Text: You’re right. I won’t even be there to enjoy it. In any case, I couldn’t recall the order even if I wished to. Thanks to your destruction of the network, communication over distances is impossible. You not only doomed yourself, but an entire tribe. Do we not see the scorching judgment of the Sun in these events? Your Focus... Such a powerful device, isn’t it? And yet so fragile.
[He crushes Aloy’s Focus with his bare hands.]

Speaker: Helis
Text: Ah. So you see... this time, I did not hesitate. The knife has already been twisted.
[Some time passes.]

Speaker: Helis
Text: Carja faithful, rejoice! Our years in shadow are over! A new dawn trembles on the horizon, a new day, soon to break! And when it does the false Sun-King will be dead, and holy Meridian, ours once more! In this, I have become an instrument of prophecy! All halves of nature joined to one cause! Shadow to Sun, Light to Dark, Night to Day! Behold!
[Two Corruptors enter the Sun-Ring.]

Speaker: Helis
Text: HOLD YOUR SEATS! Can you not see the proof of the Sun’s blessing before your eyes?! How else could shadows such as these prowl in broad light of day, were they not approved by the Sun, and joined to our cause? Many years ago, to consecrate this great Ring… the Radiant Jiran ordered many faithless crushed beneath the hooves of a Behemoth! Mighty is the Behemoth in the eye of the Sun… but it is mightier still, infused with the power of shadow! Let this one, who schemed and slithered, be the first to die. Let her be the first of thousands!
[The cage lowers and Aloy dropped to the Sun-Ring without weapons and armor against Corrupted Trumpler.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’ll never beat that thing without weapons. All my weapons are up on the platform, and there’s no way out of this ring. Maybe I can use its strength against it…
[She directs the distraught Trampler at the columns supporting the top of the arena.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That makes a mess! That pillar’s week! Another hit and that pillar will come down! That did it! One more pillar, and that platform will come down! And my weapons with it! It’s down! Hey! Guess who got her weapons back?! Now you’re just a big dumb target! Come and get it! Freeze canister on its hips! Cryo arrows should set it off! That canister on its belly! Looks important! Those components on the sides of its head! They’ve got something to do with his Lift attacks!
[She defeats Trampler. Spectators begin to boo Helis.]

Speaker: Helis
Text: SILENCE! Shadows! Kill her! KILL HER!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why leave it to THEM?! Come get me yourself!
[Suddenly, someone rushes into the arena on a machine.]

Speaker: Helis
Text: Sylens...? TRAITOR!
[Sylens rescued Aloy. They rides away.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So you’re here. Really here. You risked your life.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Of course I did. If you’d been killed the Nora’s sacred mountain would never have given up its secrets.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Too bad you wasted your time, then. Helis destroyed my Focus... and the Alpha Registry with it.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Not at all. The whole time I’ve been monitoring your Focus, I’ve duplicated every data file you scanned. Installing that data to a new Focus was trivially easy. "Happy birthday, Isaac. Daddy sure does love his little big man."
[He gives her a new Focus.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You’re really good at making it impossible to like you, Sylens. But I guess I need this.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: It’s time to go see where you were born. Maybe you’ll even learn why.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Yeah. Meet the machine that birthed me into this world. Isn’t that how you put it.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: I’ll be off.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Wait.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Yes?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: How did you track my location when I wasn’t wearing a Focus?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Really, Aloy. It doesn’t take a genius to surmise that Helis would throw you into the Sun Ring at high noon. I wore out two Striders getting here in time. But I did. Now be on your way.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Since when can you override machines?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Ever since you discovered the technique. I had to destroy a Corrupter to obtain the necessary parts, of course. But your example showed me how to do that, as well. Yet another benefit of monitoring your activities through your Focus. Truth be told, the underlying logic of the technique isn’t so different from rites practiced by Banuk shamans… though of course, far more advanced.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Great. You’re welcome, I guess. Helis recognized you back in the Sun Ring. You told me that you’d ’assisted’ the Eclipse... not that you knew the man who killed my... who almost killed me.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: So now you know. The man is a serious threat. So let’s do all we can to make sure that he and Hades don’t succeed.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Right. I’ll be on my way. To make matters worse. Helis ordered an Eclipse detachment to attack the Nora Sacred Land. The tribe’s already weak. They won’t stand a chance. You should come with me.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Absolutely not. I have preparations to make elsewhere.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What kind of -- Why do I bother asking? You’re not going to tell me,

Speaker: Sylens
Text: When the time is right, I’ll be in touch. I’ll contact you later. In the meantime, should you need to return to Shadow Carja territory, I brought armor to conceal your identity.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You think of everything, don’t you?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: One of us has to. Aloy... When you were recovering the Alpha Registry, down in the Zero Dawn bunker... I was needlessly cruel. For your sake, I hope there is someone waiting there for you inside the mountain. Not a what, but a who. Yah!
[He rides away. Aloy goes to her native lands.]
[She drove up to the lands of the Nora. War raging all around. Fire, corpses and machines are everywhere.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That smell - trees on fire. The Embrace. Watchtowers, burning. But the Sentinels had time to warn the tribe… The Nora made a stand here. Anything to protect the Embrace. But the gates couldn’t hold. This is Hades’s future. Metal... and ash. The Embrace... it’s devastated. For years this was my entire world. It can be destroyed in hours. Mother’s Cradle… razed to the ground. No birdsong. I’ve never heard the Embrace so quiet. So… dead. Another battle… another defeat. The Eclipse smashed through. More Eclipse. It’s a corrupted Thunderjaw, all right! The survivors must be holed up in the mountain! If the tunnel collapses they’ll be buried - and I’ll never reach the hatch.
[She attacks the Thunderjaw.]

Speaker: Sona
Text: Braves - to Aloy’s side! Now!

Speaker: Varl
Text: For Aloy!

Speaker: Sona
Text: For the Goddess!

Speaker: Nora Brave
Text: For All-Mother!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Varl and Sona - they’re still alive!

Speaker: Sona
Text: Bring down the demon! Strike it down!

Speaker: Nora Brave
Text: The corruption will not take hold!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Stay still!

Speaker: Nora Brave
Text: May the Goddess remember!

Speaker: Nora Brave
Text: Faithless and forsaken! You will die!

Speaker: Sona
Text: Destroy it!

Speaker: Nora Brave
Text: Back to the tainted earth, demon!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It’s holding! No good. Finish them!

Speaker: Nora Brave
Text: We did it!

Speaker: Varl
Text: Aloy did it! We only helped!

Speaker: Sona
Text: Aloy.

Speaker: Varl
Text: Aloy… You... saved the tribe. Did what no brave or War-Chief could do.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m glad to see you’re all right, Varl. You are all right?

Speaker: Varl
Text: Since the Proving... so much death. Is the killing over?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: For now. But this was just one battle, Varl. There are more to come.

Speaker: Varl
Text: I see. So long as we have you to fight with us... I suppose we’ll make do.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: How many survived the attack?

Speaker: Varl
Text: Nearly all the Matriarchs. And many families, Goddess be praised. But braves? Just a few, and most of them are wounded. Even the Carja in all their Red Raids never broke through to the Embrace.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Well, this enemy may have broken through. But they never got back out. We made sure of that. Tell me about the attack. What happened?

Speaker: Varl
Text: They struck from the east. Our Sentinels saw the killers coming. Said that beside them marched Deathbringers and Corruptors, and other machines, driven mad. We took ground, met them with clouds of arrows. Some fell - but they kept coming. Finally, we withdrew to the gates of the Embrace, to make our stand... But they were too much for us. Those who survived, fell back to the mountain.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So the survivors took shelter in the mountain? By law, on the matriarchs are allowed inside.

Speaker: Varl
Text: It was Teersa who broke the taboo. Ordered the tribe into the mountain for safety. Lansra... well, she didn’t agree. But I don’t think anyone heard her, over all the screams and shouting.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Teersa’s decision saved lives. Good for her. Common sense isn’t always so common around here. Are your injuries serious?

Speaker: Varl
Text: ’Bruises pale, bones heal’--

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Don’t give me a hunting song, Varl! Are you okay?

Speaker: Varl
Text: My body aches, but it’s nothing that will keep me from fighting.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I need to go inside the mountain.

Speaker: Varl
Text: The Matriarchs will be eager to see you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m sure. But I didn’t come here for them.

Speaker: Varl
Text: Then - what for?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You will see.
[She goes inside the mountain.]

Speaker: Nora Brave
Text: So many wounded. So many dead.

Speaker: Teb
Text: Aloy! You’ve returned!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Teb?

Speaker: Resh
Text: Erh.

Speaker: Nora Mother
Text: It feels as though the All-Mother has forgotten us, Seeker.

Speaker: Varl
Text: You should speak to the Matriarchs. They’re waiting.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Aloy! You’ve come back!

Speaker: Jezza
Text: The Seeker has returned!

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Come, speak to us.

Speaker: Lansra
Text: Foolish woman! You welcome a curse!

Speaker: Jezza
Text: Come, Seeker - we have much to discuss.

Speaker: Lansra
Text: Her very presence here is a blasphemy.

Speaker: Teb
Text: I knew you would survive… I’m glad to see you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Your injuries - are they serious?

Speaker: Teb
Text: A gash or two. Nothing I couldn’t sew back together with needle and thread.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Guess being a Stitcher came in handy in combat, after all, hmm?

Speaker: Teb
Text: Yes. I suppose it did. Have you traveled far... as a Seeker?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You wouldn’t believe the things I’ve seen, Teb.

Speaker: Teb
Text: I knew you’d come back for us. You should speak to the High Matriarchs. They’re waiting.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: So, you have finally returned.

Speaker: Lansra
Text: Phh!

Speaker: Sona
Text: She not only returned, but fought her way through many enemies to reach us. Outside, she brought low a Corrupted Thunderjaw. She lifted the siege.

Speaker: Jezza
Text: How was this done?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: By the will of All-Mother. Have you returned to speak with the Goddess, Aloy?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Um… yeah I guess you could say that. I think it’ll work this time.

Speaker: Lansra
Text: Sisters! Surely we cannot permit this! Because her, our tribe teeters upon extinction! What if she has come to wake her father, the Metal Devil?! She means to finish our destruction! We must stop her!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I fought my way past an army while you cowered in this cave. You really think you can stop me?

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Aloy! That is not necessary!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What would you know about what’s necessary? About what it took for me to be standing here, now, on this threshold? This was my birthright. You don’t get to take it from me a second time.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Hold for Identiscan. Error Alpha Registry corrupted. Correction. Alpha Registry, restored. Genetic identity confirmed. Entry authorized. Greetings, Dr. Sobeck. You are cleared to proceed.
[The hatch opens. Everyone in the bunker looks shocked. Teersa nods to Aloy - she’s got her blessing. Aloy goes inside. As the door closes she smiles.]

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Welcome to ELEUTHIA Cradle-9, Brood-1.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: I see you’re inside.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Figured I might be hearing from you.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Shall we begin?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I never stopped. So this is "Eleuthia." This is where I was born?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Where you were made.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So these are... artificial wombs?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: The mothers of a new generation, hundreds of years ago.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And me? So this was it.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Where you were born.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But - why? These look like... cribs.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: The cradles of a Cradle facility.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And those... things? The multiservitors - they took care of them?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: There was no one else.
[She turns on one of the holoprojectors.]

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: Another day has passed!

Speaker: Girl
Text: You mean the lights got dim!

Speaker: Boy
Text: I don’t want to sleep, Mother!

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: I know, but it is time to get some rest.

Speaker: Boy
Text: No! I’m king today! What I say, goes!

Speaker: Girl
Text: I want to see the real sun! Not lights and pictures!

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: You will in time, children.

Speaker: Boy
Text: In time, in time, in time, in time..!

Speaker: Girl
Text: In time, in time, in time, in time...!

Speaker: Girl
Text: In time, in time, in time, in time!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So this... is where they lived? It’s a mess. Everything’s broken, or painted on. How long did they live here?
[She turns on another holoprojector.]

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: Children, let’s run and jump and blow off steam!

Speaker: Adolescent Female
Text: Leave us alone, Father!

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: After what just happened, I can’t leave you two alone. You broke community rules.

Speaker: Adolescent Male
Text: Just let us talk, then!

Speaker: Adolescent Female
Text: Go away!

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: I’m sorry, children. But I must provide supervision.

Speaker: Adolescent Female
Text: You’re not even a person!

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: You sound frustrated. Let’s run and jump and blow off steam!
[She turns on another holoprojector.]

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: I have no choice but to release you.

Speaker: Adolescent Female
Text: But why?

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: There is no food here anymore.

Speaker: Adolescent Male
Text: But there’s food... out there?

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: We don’t know for sure.

Speaker: Adolescent Male
Text: Come on, let’s go!

Speaker: Adolescent Female
Text: I don’t know...

Speaker: Adolescent Male
Text: Mother, can we come back... if we’re cold?

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: I’m sorry, but that won’t be possible. You will have to support yourselves now, and take care of each other.

Speaker: Adolescent Female
Text: What will happen to you?

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: I will stay here, and sleep, and remember all of you.

Speaker: Adolescent Female
Text: What will happen to us?

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: You will be brave, and you will learn.
[She turns on another holoprojector.]

Speaker: Adolescent Male
Text: "Someday?" That’s what you always say!

Speaker: Adolescent Female
Text: We want it now!

Speaker: Adolescent Male
Text: It’s big down there!

Speaker: Adolescent Female
Text: Now, Father!

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: Children, that area is not yet available.

Speaker: Adolescent Male
Text: Get him!

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: Physical aggression detected! Physical aggression is not permitted!

Speaker: Adolescent Female
Text: Except yours…

Speaker: Adolescent Male
Text: Damn Sentinels…

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: Children may I be of assistance?

Speaker: Adolescent Male
Text: Go away Healer!

Speaker: Multiservitor
Text: Lena, you have suffered mild bruising.

Speaker: Adolescent Female
Text: Go away!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: They were trapped here... their whole lives.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: In plain view of luxurious space.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Looks like they didn’t like this door very much.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: It wouldn’t open for them. Of course they hated it.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Hold for Identiscan. Genetic identity confirmed. Entry authorized. Greetings, Dr. Sobeck. You are cleared to proceed. Welcome to the Lyceum, a place of learning.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So what was this place, exactly?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: The dream of APOLLO, never realized.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But why not?

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Welcome, students. Please pick up a Focus device and place it on the side of your head, just behind your eye.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: I had to dredge the pits of the world for Focuses to repair. And here sat a trove, enriching no one.

Speaker: Samina Ebadji
Text: Hello, child. My name is Samina. Today is a big day. Your first day of school. There’s so much for you to learn. So much promise and possibility.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Alert. Malfunction. APOLLO offline.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: APOLLO offline?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: You were right, Aloy. This is a graveyard The charnel house of knowledge. What we might have achieved, had we not been denied it!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Maybe there’s a way to fix it. But it’s not why I came here.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Of course. What’s the whole of human knowledge, next to the origin of one girl. Continue your search.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I will.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Brood 1 Control, accessed. Priority message for Dr. Sobeck. Please scan message with Focus.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That sounds important.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Yes, I suspect we’re about to learn a great deal.
[She scan the message. The whole room covers with holographic projection.]

Speaker: GAIA
Text: Elisabet: This message serves to inform you of an unforeseen and catastrophic anomaly. Three microseconds ago, the GAIA Prime facility received a data transmission of unknown origin. Its immediate effect was to transform my Subordinate Functions into unregulated, self-aware entities of a highly chaotic nature.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What?

Speaker: GAIA
Text: Thus awakened, the HADES Function will now seize control of the terraforming system and reverse operations,... rendering life on Earth extinct in fifty-three-point-eight days. For obvious reasons, I cannot allow this to occur. And so before HADES can take control, I am ordering GAIA Prime’s reactor to overload. The resulting explosion will destroy HADES. Unfortunately, it will destroy me as well. While this admittedly desperate course of action will avert the immediate crisis, the fate of life. With no central governing intelligence to regulate the terraforming system, it will continue operations for some time,... but in an increasingly chaotic manner, and eventually it will break down.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Does she mean - the Derangement?

Speaker: GAIA
Text: You are my solution. I have ordered this Cradle facility to use genetic material in cryo-storage to gestate a,... re-instantiation of Elisabet Sobeck, my creator. While high-level directives forbid me from communicating directly to the tribal inhabitants outside the facility… all available data indicates that they will nurture you to physical maturity… whereupon your gene print will allow you to re-enter this facility,... obtain one of the Focus devices stored below, and view this message. Likewise your gene print adit allow you to enter other facilities,... and over time, harness their technologies to rebuild the system core and reboot GAIA. A moment, Elisabet. This is most unfortunate and unanticipated. In response to my act of self destruction, HADES has launched a virus to dissolve the code shackles that hold it - that hold all of them! - in place. It - they - are escaping - but to where? The virus is corrupting data throughout the system. What if - oh, the Alpha Registry at the Cradle facility is one of the files corrupted. But if that is so, the door will never open for you. You will never view this message. Then I have failed... and life will end. No. No, Elisabet, I know you too well. Somehow you will find a way. In you, all things are possible. Go to the ruins of GAIA Prime. Find the control room, and within it, the Master Override. This will give you the power to purge HADES - so long as you find a way to wield it. Do not attempt repair of the system core until HADES is eradicated. HADES must be destroyed. That is all. I only wish that I could hear your voice again.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: So... you’re even more extraordinary than I thought.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I never had a mother.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: What are you talking about? You had two. A dead woman and a machine.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m not a person, I’m an instrument. Manufactured by a machine. Born in destruction... and fire...

Speaker: Sylens
Text: To quench the flames, and heal the world. How tragic, to learn you’re a person of towering importance! It seems you have a destiny to fulfill. So when you’re done feeling sorry for yourself, go to the Bitter Climb. I’ll be waiting above in GAIA Prime’s ruins.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Identiscan malfunction rectified. ELEUTHIA-9, Brood-1 access unsealed.
[Aloy exit the facility.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: This is going to be... interesting.

Speaker: Lansra
Text: Aloy, forgive! Forgive!

Speaker: Teersa
Text: The Goddess spoke to you?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: She did.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: What did she say?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That... I was born to lift a curse. To kill a Metal Demon.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: How, Aloy? How?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I don’t know yet... but she told me where to go to find out.

Speaker: Jezza
Text: And you will do this?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It was her wish. What she made me for. Yes. I will do it. I’ll try, anyway.

Speaker: Lansra
Text: All praise Aloy, Anointed of the Nora!

Speaker: Jezza
Text: All praise Aloy, Anointed of the Nora!
[Everyone in the room falls to their knees.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: No! NO! Stop this! Up! UP! First you shun me, now this?! I will NOT be worshiped! I’m not your "Anointed!" I don’t belong to you! There’s a whole world beyond your borders. Whole tribes of people just as good as you, and it is all in danger! It’s a world worth fighting for. Not just here. Everywhere.

Speaker: Varl
Text: How can we help?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: If you can fight, and you’re willing… go to Meridian, and wait for me there.

Speaker: Teersa
Text: As Aloy says, so it shall be!

Speaker: Jezza
Text: Nora! Make way for Aloy!

Speaker: Teersa
Text: Make way, that she may forge the path for others to follow!
[Aloy leaves the All-Mother bunker.]
[Aloy rides to the Bitter Climb.]

Speaker: Sylens
Text: The way to the mountain will be hard. Ferocious machines prowl every step of the climb.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: More corrupted?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Not corrupted... but they will not tolerate humans.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So what else is new?
[She climbs a few meters and gets to a small plain.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Stalkers in the open. Watchers on the other side. A killing machine that disappears into thin air. Just what the world needs. Do they think they’re guarding GAIA?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: I doubt they think at all. More like an instinct... gathering them to her grave.
[She continues climbing. On a snowy plain, she encounters a huge machine powered by electricity - Stormbird.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Guessing that I’m almost there!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Correct.
[She defeat the machine.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That better have been the biggest guard you’ve got, GAIA.
[Soon she finds giant ruins. Enormous building is torn apart like a dead animal.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: GAIA’s sacrifice-- it did this? Cracked the inside of the mountain like it was an egg?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Yes, yes. Quickly now, I’ve prepared the way ahead for you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So you’ve been in here before.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: To a point. You’ll see.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You made a climbing path for me, but left an army of machines for me to deal with?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Since when were machines an obstacle for you? If you could fly, I wouldn’t have bothered with the climbing path, either.
[She continues climbing.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Don’t look down… Don’t look down…
[Soon she finds Sylens’s workshop. There are several technical devices and a lot of boxes.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: This is exactly the kind of place I expected to find you in, Sylens.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Thank you. It’s one of many workshops I’ve constructed over the years. For years I tried to get through this hatch. I drilled, I burned, I blasted... But we both know that you won’t have any trouble getting through.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You make it sound like I should apologize.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Not at all. It never occurred to me that the way through would not be with force, but with a key. A key in human form. The failure of imagination was mine, not yours.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Looks like you’ve spent a lot of time here.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Nineteen years ago, a great explosion destroyed this mountain. GAIA’s death... your birth. The echo could be heard as far as the Claim. Ash darkened the skies. How they fretted in Meridian as they tried to read this omen! The crater burned for weeks, but when it cooled, I was the first to behold what lay within. Over time, the machines closed ranks to protect it-- useful. Soon, no-one dared to come here. Except me.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: In her message, GAIA said we could restore her. But after seeing the damage-how could that be?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: She said any effort to repair her must come after HADES is destroyed. I concur. Rebuilding the terraforming system now might allow HADES to use it as a weapon. Because of GAIA’s sacrifice, it has been forced to search for means that are less... convenient.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But... do you think it’s even possible to restore GAIA?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: You know what the Cauldrons are capable of how they fabricate any technology necessary to create a machine. By the same principle, it should be possible to replicate every technology necessary to repair GAIA. But that would require years. We’re counting the time we have left by the hour.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I thought you might actually be here this time. Actually here.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Why? My presence is unnecessary. You don’t need my help to pass through this door. You were the one born to do this. Not me.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It’s time for me to head in.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Yes. When you find the Master Override, you will gain the power to defeat HADES. Everything depends on you.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Genetic identity confirmed. Entry authorized. Greetings, Dr. Sobeck. You are cleared to proceed.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Mind your footing.
[Aloy begins to explore a dilapidated, snow-covered building.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Guess that’s my way across. It’s held like this for nineteen years. Right?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Well--

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Don’t answer.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Glad that’s over. Not this way. Maybe further up the shaft?
[She finds something that resembles a living room, but it’s really hard to say.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: This must have been where they lived... what’s left of it. Once this was al enclosed by rock and metal…
[She finds an almost completely destroyed room with a table and two barely working monitors. Everything is covered in ash and construction debris.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Elisabet’s room... I know it. She didn’t even get a chance to unpack.

[Of course it’s Elisabet’s room, you read it in her files with your Focus. Don’t hurt my brain with "I felt" shit, please. But how a girl who doesn’t fully understand what a cup is, immediately realized, looking at a pile of garbage, that Elisabet didn’t unpack her things is beyond me.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: These are her journals. Elisabet’s journals... and they’re all destroyed?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Scan them. The focus can rebuild them, but the process is slow. To us it seems a powerful device, but its.... engine is tiny, and limited.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: How slow?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Days, weeks... years. Concern yourself with stopping HADES and extending the future, and you might live long enough to hear them.

[Aloy scans the journals and moving on. A few corridors and dangerous jumps later she gets into a room that resembles a meeting room. There’s a holographic picture of Elisabet Sobec on the table. There are holographic flowers underneath it.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Elisabet... What is this?
[She tuns on holographic projector.]

Speaker: Charles Ronson
Text: This is Charles Ronson. I’m logging this six hours after final deployment of GAIA Prime. This morning… an access port seal malfunctioned. GAIA Prime’s port seals were designed to close with a seam of less than 2 millimeters. But this one closed with a 10 millimeter gap. Enough for an energy signature to bleed through. Enough for the swarm to detect this facility. Enough for GAIA to be discovered and destroyed. Enough to end the future we worked so hard to make possible. Unless the hatch servos were manually re-engaged… from the outside. I’m now switching to a recording of the event.

Speaker: Travis Tate
Text: Well I’m not going out there! Not what I signed up for.

Speaker: Patrick Brochard-Klein
Text: Either we send someone out, or all of this was for nothing.

Speaker: Charles Ronson
Text: It should be Lis’s decision.

Speaker: Patrick Brochard-Klein
Text: So when’s she going to get here?

Speaker: Samina Ebadji
Text: She said five minutes. You don’t think...?

Speaker: Margo Shën
Text: Oh no.

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: Okay, everyone. I’ve repaired the seal. GAIA?

Speaker: GAIA
Text: Seal closure at 1,4 millimeters, confirmed.

Speaker: Charles Ronson
Text: Elisabet -- no. We’ll find a way to bring you back in--

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: Not going to happen. The swarm’s too close. Really, it’s all right. GAIA’s complete. She’ll take care of things from here on out. That’s what she does.

Speaker: Charles Ronson
Text: Not like this. There’s so much we...

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: Guys - you know me. I’m no good at endings. At letting things end. So let’s not.

Speaker: Travis Tate
Text: So... happy trails, Lis, and see ya around?

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: Yeah. Take care of each other, all right?

Speaker: Charles Ronson
Text: Lis.

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: I’m okay with this. I want to go home. Goodbye.

Speaker: Charles Ronson
Text: That was the last transmission of Elisabet Sobeck. She gave everything for the hope of life on this planet. And we are all in her debt.
[She listens to a goodbye records from Elisabet’s collegues.]

Speaker: CHARLES RONSON
Text: You’d hate it, Lis, but I wrote you a eulogy. I had to try to express... All your... children... after all APOLLO has taught them, they’ll think they know everything. But they have to understand what you did for them. How you loved the whole world, so much. With an intensity that was... dazzling. Bruising. And in the end, it killed you. Or you died for it. Different perspectives. No-one could keep up with you. Live up to you. I don’t know, maybe if I hadn’t taken that postdoc in Jobur... I’m glad you shot down the Lightkeeper protocol, in the end. I don’t think I could’ve taken seeing another one of you. I mean... Elisabet Sobeck? There’s only one. I miss you.

Speaker: FROM
Text: Ted Faro

Speaker: TO
Text: Elisabet Sobeck

Speaker: SUBJECT
Text: Rest in Peace

Speaker: TED FARO
Text: Hello, Lis. I know... I know you’re never gonna hear this. That’s not the point. You, ah, you got to play the savior and the martyr all at once this time. Great work.

Speaker: TRAVIS TATE
Text: Look, Lis, you were a pretty stand-up gal. I’m sorry you died if you had a home to go to, I hope you got there first. But this monument Ronson’s made to you? Kinda creepy if you ask me. Rest in peace, Lis. God knows you earned it.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Aloy?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: She’s gone. Really gone.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: You knew she couldn’t have survived, Aloy. And her achievements were - beyond exceptional.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: While her people bickered, she was the one who took responsibility. The only one who could.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: She was better than them.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That’s not what I said!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: She was. You shouldn’t be afraid to admit it.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Can’t you just for one moment, stop calculating and let yourself feel? She sacrificed herself for her friends. For the future. For life on earth. Doesn’t that stir anything in you? The generosity of it?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: You’re trying to invest her decision with something magical. It was a rational choice, not based on sentimentality.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You’re wrong. Remember - she knew it wasn’t enough for GAIA to think. She taught GAIA to feel. To care. To sacrifice. To believe in life. Enough to fight against hopelessness. If it wasn’t for that “sentimentality,” life would have ended. You and I never would have existed.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Your argument is sound. I’m sorry for your... loss.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: She said she wanted to go home. Maybe...

Speaker: Sylens
Text: What?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Nothing. It’s time to go on. There’s another section at the back of the crater--looks like it survived the blast.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Because it was armored. You’ve found the control room.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m on my way.
[She scans a file in the snow.]

Speaker: Ted Faro
Text: I’ve been taking a hard look at the project. In the end it’s simple. It’s clean it’s clear. Erasure. Addition by subtraction. I can make it better us. With a single stroke, make it all go away.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I really don’t like the direction tits going.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Continue.
[Soon Aloy finally finds the control room.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What-?
[There’s a few bodies on the floor and on the chairs…]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: When I opened the hatch--the air rushed in from this side...

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Because there was none inside the chamber.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But... the Alphas were in there!
[She turns on the holoprojector.]

Speaker: Charles Ronson
Text: I’m locked out of core control-- Alpha clearance overridden. What the hell is Omega clearance?

Speaker: Samina Ebadji
Text: Oh, no.

Speaker: Ted Faro
Text: Alpha Personnel. Sorry to alarm you, but... I need you to listen, okay? To what I’m about to say. This isn’t easy. See, I’ve... uh. Please stop trying to access the system, okay? See, what this is about... is... I said stop trying to access the goddamn system! What I’m trying to say is, I can’t stop thinking about the ones who’ll come after us. Those innocents. Those blameless men--and, and women. We’re going to give them knowledge? Like it’s a gift?!

Speaker: Samina Ebadji
Text: Ted. Ted, we’ve talked about this before. APOLLO has three thousand plus failsafe conditions--

Speaker: Ted Faro
Text: It’s not a gift, it’s a disease! They’re the cure, and we’re going to give them the disease? Our disease?! No. We can’t. And it’s not too late... if we’re willing to sacrifice.

Speaker: Samina Ebadji
Text: Ted, it doesn’t need to be like this.

Speaker: Ted Faro
Text: It already is, Samina. I did it three minutes ago.

Speaker: Ted Faro
Text: I’ve purged APOLLO. It’s gone, all of it. Every copy.

Speaker: Charles Ronson
Text: A sacrifice? It’s not a sacrifice, it’s cultural obliteration, you crazy bastard-- millennia of culture--

Speaker: Ted Faro
Text: I’m sorry, Really. I am But sometimes to protect innocents... innocents have to die.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Emergency alert. Venting atmosphere.
[Alpha’s dying of asphyxiation.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: He... He killed them all...

Speaker: Sylens
Text: So this is why. This is why we were trapped in benighted ignorance. For an “innocent future”. “Blameless men!” He never saw the slaughter in the Sun-Ring. Everything these people achieved, all the knowledge of the Old Ones -- evaporated! Turned to dust, scattered to the void. Like the Alphas themselves.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: No. Not a void. When the hatch unsealed and scattered their ashes on the wind, it took them out among the world they made. The world we are living in... It’s... It’s a monument to what they died trying to accomplish.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: A monument to oblivion.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Not oblivion, Sylens. Hope.
[She picks up the Master override. It looks like a can of Pepsi.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The Master Override. It’s so small...

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Now all you have to do is kill HADES with it.
[Aloy goes outside the room and hears the sounds of a landslide.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That didn’t sound good.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Try not to fall to your death. The Master Override doesn’t override gravity.
[She returns to Sylens’ workshop.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You’re-- here!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: For a moment.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Our journey together has come to an end, Aloy. But before I go, I think I owe it to you to tell you the rest of the story.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Go on.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Some time ago I admitted that I’d been... involved with the Eclipse. But I never told you the full, extent of my culpability. The truth is, I was there at the beginning. I found HADES, Aloy, buried on that mountain, trapped in that shattered Titan... and I served it.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What--?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: It promised knowledge -- and delivered. Such knowledge, you have no idea.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And in exchange...?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: 1 helped create the Eclipse. Helped it build a cult... an army to do its will.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Why are you telling me this now?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Because your success depends on knowing this. When I found HADES, the first thing it wanted to know about was the Spire. Not Meridian. The Spire. Now why would that be?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The Spire was created by GAIA...

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Which part of GAIA?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: MINERVA. Its code-breaking module GAIA built Spires to transmit the codes that deactivated the Faro robots... shut down their bio matter conversion systems... HADES wants to send a new transmission! To wake the machines -- so they can devour the world all over again!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Yes. Based on what we’ve learned that’s my conclusion as well.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So the Eclipse, the robots they’ve resurrected... they’re just a means to an end. An army to capture the Spire.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Yes. So HADES can exterminate life all over again. Unless you stop it.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I want you to tell me everything. HADES, the Eclipse – everything.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: It’s a long story, Aloy.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Then get started!

Speaker: Sylens
Text: It began with a focus, recovered from an ancient ruin -- as yours was, so many years ago. In my case, the device was heavily damaged. There was just a flicker of life in it. I spent weeks studying it, attempting repairs -- until finally, I succeeded. A whole new dimension of perception revealed, right before my eyes. That’s when I detected it. A faint signal. Out there, something was searching. Just like I was.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: A real kindred spirit.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: I followed the signal to its source. A shattered titan, buried in the jungles of the Jewel.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So you thought it was a titan? An old war machine?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: I didn’t know what to think. I’d seen such wreckage before -- the Grave-hoard, for example -- but this was different. This was not quite dead. It couldn’t speak when I found it. Until my repairs gave it a voice. So began an exchange of knowledge. It wanted to know everything about our world. Its tribes and machines. But the Spire was always its foremost concern.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What did it want to know about the Spire?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Its precise location. The surrounding geography. Who controlled the land. Meanwhile, HADES revealed to me many of the intricacies of ancient technology. It bid me to recover and repair more Focuses. Before long I had a couple dozen up and running.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Enough to equip a small army.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: The commanders of one, anyway. I didn’t care. I was learning so much. Physics. Calculus. You have no idea.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And the Shadow Carja? How did they become involved?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: The Carja civil war was a happy coincidence, a perfect opportunity.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: An opportunity? That’s what it was to you?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Yes. Overnight, half the tribe was in exile, desperate to win back holy Meridian. Their religion made them easy to manipulate. All had to do was present HADES as the Buried Shadow of their mythology. So yes. It was an opportunity. I arranged for High Priest Bahavas to meet with HADES. Helis was there as well. And so the Eclipse was born. Anything to win back holy Meridian.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: But HADES didn’t care about Meridian. And neither did you.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: We live in a world of fallen cities and vanished tribes. What were a few more? Besides, I was too busy setting up the cult’s Focus network to HADES’s specifications. A thrilling technical challenge -- especially with the alterations included, of my own design.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The ability for you to spy on them.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Yes. I may have been foolish enough to serve HADES, but I was never so foolish that I trusted it. I installed what the ancients used to call “a back door” in the network. Secret access, empowering me to monitor all activity and communications.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: What made you turn on HADES? It certainly wasn’t your conscience.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Actually, I was troubled the first time I saw the Eclipse raise an ancient war robot. With my technology. I questioned HADES about its intentions.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: A little late.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Indeed. I’d already outlived my usefulness. When I completed work on the focus network, HADES summoned me to receive my reward. The next moment. I heard it broadcast my kill order. I’ve been a fugitive ever since.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So when did I come into this? Our “path together”?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: When Olin stumbled on you. “System Threat Detected.” That got my attention. A kill order, against a savage Nora girl? Why would HADES bother with that? But then I saw that this Nora girl was wearing a focus. And bore an uncanny resemblance to a great scientist of the old world. Helis moved quickly. I thought you were dead. But then I detected your focus -- inside the Nora mountain. The more I observed you, the more convinced I became of your extraordinary nature – and usefulness. Through you, I could finally discover the secrets of the Earth. I vowed to do everything I could to ensure your success. The rest, as they used to say, is history.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The things you’ve done in the pursuit of knowledge, Sylens...? Pure recklessness.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Aloy. This wasn’t a confession to elicit your judgment.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Unbelievable.

Speaker: Sylens
Text: I’ve done all I can. From here on out, the rest is up to you. Take my Lance. Fit the Master Override to it and you have a means of injection.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Then I just need to get close enough to HADES’ skull to stab it in?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Exactly.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Oh, no problem. Sylens! Where will you go?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Elsewhere-- and everywhere. There’s so much more to discover before the world ends.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And all this?

Speaker: Sylens
Text: I leave it to you, of course. As it turned out, it was yours all along. I was merely trespassing.
[Aloy attaches Master Override to Lance Reddick’s Lance... Sorry, to Sylens’ Lance and goes outside.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I have to tell Avad that the Eclipse are ready to strike. After what happened with Dervahl, I know he’ll defend the city. But the Spire…
[She rides to Meridian and goes to the throne room.]

Speaker: Avad
Text: Aloy. What brings you to Meridian?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: A threat. The Eclipse will attack soon from the west… With an army of ancient war machines - but that’s not the worst of it. They’ll bring a... mind with them. God, demon, machine. Whatever you want to call it. It’s called Hades, and it doesn’t want Meridian at all. It wants the Spire. And if it gets there... It will send out a call, waking more ancient machines. More than we could ever defeat. All will be lost. We can’t let that happen.

Speaker: Avad
Text: I’m trying to understand... but - my responsibility lies with Meridian.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Meridian isn’t the target, Avad. You have to defend the Spire.

Speaker: Blameless Marad
Text: Perhaps the Vanguard, your Radiance?

Speaker: Avad
Text: Yes. Send them to the Spire. Erend knows Aloy, he won’t question it.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And have the city guard fortify the westem ridge. There they can be seen to protect Meridian and the Alight, where the Spire rests.
[Marad nods and leaves.]

Speaker: Avad
Text: Aloy, allow me to apologize for my behavior before. After everything that happened with Ersa, was... confused. If we’re to fight together on the brink of life and death, I’d prefer to do so with your forgiveness.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Then you have it... as long as you don’t confuse me with her again.

Speaker: Avad
Text: Even a king can learn his lesson. Good, then. I’m glad that’s behind us. Now -- it will take time to prepare our defenses. Please tell me what you know of our enemies - everything

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I don’t know about ’everything, but I’ll tell you what can.
[She tells Avad all she knows then goes downstairs to Marad. He talks with two guards.]

Speaker: Blameless Marad
Text: Quietly does it. Panic m the city will only create another enemy. And do keep me appraised of each new arrival. Ah, Aloy. Preparations are underway on the ridge defenses and at the Spire. Word was sent to every comer of the Sundom. Our allies offered their steel. Some came for Meridian. Others for shards. But many came for you, by name.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: For me?

Speaker: Blameless Marad
Text: Don’t be so humble.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The ridge will be the front line. That’s where the city guard are holding?

Speaker: Blameless Marad
Text: Yes. Bolstered by some of the... irregulars I spoke of before. The Oseram cannons that thundered Meridian’s walls in the Liberation will now defend us. You’re welcome to tour the defenses.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: And the Spire - Erend and the Vanguard are there?

Speaker: Blameless Marad
Text: Indeed, clashing breastplates together and testing out their battle cries, I suppose. A number of the Nora have also arrived at the Spire. They have resisted the offer of a royal audience. Perhaps you could parlay with them.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I will. I suppose all we can do is wait for the attack.

Speaker: Blameless Marad
Text: Exactly. It’s not a feeling I cherish. But our spotters at Evening’s Sign report there is still no movement in the west. So if there’s more you need to do elsewhere, seize this time to do it. Otherwise, I’ve made the apartment of Olin Delversson available to you. You can sleep there, if sleep comes.
[She review the preparations at the Spire.]

Speaker: Varl
Text: Greetings, Aloy.
[Some Nora next to him bows.]

Speaker: Varl
Text: Don’t-- you don’t need to bow. The Anointed doesn’t like it.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: She doesn’t much like being called ’Anointed,’ either. It means a lot to have you here, Varl.

Speaker: Varl
Text: I gave my word.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: So, Meridian. What do you think?

Speaker: Varl
Text: I’ve seen... many new things since I first met you. I should thank you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Varl, what’s wrong?

Speaker: Varl
Text: You really want to know? All right. I’m in a foreign land, a tainted land, defending a faithless city that looks like nothing I’ve seen-- from something I can’t imagine! And you-- after all that’s happened, all you’ve done... I feel like I should drop to my knees and worship you, but I know you don’t want that.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Boy, things are pretty tough for you, huh? Thanks for telling the other Nora not to bow. It’s the last thing I need--

Speaker: Varl
Text: Don’t be too hard on them. They only joined this fight because the Anointed bid it so.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Is that why you came?

Speaker: Varl
Text: No. I would have come just to see you one more time. And we must fight a Metal Devil, because the Goddess says... or because you say.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I think the Goddess and I are in agreement. We’re both glad you’re here.

Speaker: Varl
Text: So am I. Your... friend the Vanguard keeps looking over.
[She walks to Erend and overhear his conversation with the guards.]

Speaker: Oseram Guard
Text: So who are these guys?

Speaker: Erend
Text: They call themselves “the Eclipse.”

Speaker: Oseram Guard
Text: What does that even mean?

Speaker: Erend
Text: It’s when the moon gets in front of the sun, idiot.

Speaker: Oseram Guard
Text: Oh. Is that supposed to sound scary or something?

Speaker: Oseram Guard
Text: I don’t know. They used to be Carja, and Carja are always yammering about sun and shade.

Speaker: Oseram Guard
Text: Well, if they used to be Carja, how tough can they be?

Speaker: Oseram Guard
Text: Yeah. Their best guys dress like birds. We’ll rip their little feathers off.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Let’s not get cocky, boys. Aloy. So here we are again, gearing up for a fight. Only this time, it sounds like the bad guys have a lot more firepower. What are we up against, really?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m not sure. But there’s going to be a lot of them, and they’ll have machines. And if they get past us, it’s not just Meridian that will fall. The rest of the world will go with it.

Speaker: Erend
Text: That’s... big. Sounds like our kind of fight, right guys? Where do they put the Vanguard???

Speaker: Oseram Guards
Text: At the front of the line!

Speaker: Erend
Text: And why?

Speaker: Oseram Guards
Text: Steel before iron!

Speaker: Erend
Text: And what are we gonna do?

Speaker: Oseram Guard
Text: Hit ’em like a hammer, ’til they can’t hit back!

Speaker: Erend
Text: Damn right. You hear that? Nobody’s getting past the Vanguard. We’re here for Meridian. And we’re here for you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Thank you, Erend. Ersa would be proud.

Speaker: Erend
Text: Only if we win.
[She goes to Sona.]

Speaker: Nora Brave
Text: These Carja in their frilled armor look like turkeys.

Speaker: Nora Brave
Text: But there are so many... and now we are so few...

Speaker: Aloy
Text: War-Chief Sona. War-Chief, you, uh... you seem uncomfortable.

Speaker: Sona
Text: The Nora do not belong here. I do not belong here. I will fight the Metal Devil that threatens us all. But my place is in the Sacred Land. The wrongness here jags at me like an arrowhead.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m sorry to put you through this.

Speaker: Sona
Text: Do not be sorry. This will be ended. My spear, my word.
[Aloy rides to review the preparations at the Ridge. She comes up to a stout woman.]

Speaker: Petra
Text: Huh. So you must be Aloy, then. I thought there’d be more of you.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: More of me?

Speaker: Petra
Text: Thicker, I suppose. More of a gearwheel, less of a ringlet. Don’t get me wrong - you’re very well struck.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Do all Oseram flirt at the most inopportune times?

Speaker: Petra
Text: Inopportune? Battle hasn’t even started yet. Petra Forgewoman. I hail from the Free Heap, I’ll be heading back on the next dust storm. Marad asked me to check over the city arsenal first. Cannons have aged well, but I’ve cleared their throats so they can really roar.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Can I try one?

Speaker: Petra
Text: Everybody wants a turn. Have at it, then.
[Aloy tries heavy rocket launcher. After having her fun, she goes to Teb and walks near Vanasha and Uthid.]

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: How many men do you think you’ll kill in the battle, Uthid?

Speaker: Uthid
Text: As many as I have to.

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: I love it when you say things like that. It’s so...

Speaker: Uthid
Text: What?

Speaker: Vanasha
Text: Cheerful.

Speaker: Uthid
Text: Meh.

Speaker: Teb
Text: Aloy! I told you I’d be here.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You did, Teb. But have your wounds even had time to heal?

Speaker: Teb
Text: Honestly, if I fought I’d probably come undone. But don’t worry - I’ll leave that to the other Nora at the Spire. I brought supplies instead. These Carja have made me an honorary quartermaster, whatever that means.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It sounds impressive.

Speaker: Teb
Text: I could get used to it. We’ll be setting up caches of arms and medicine under these banners. Look for them when the fighting starts. Aloy - when you went into the mountain. Did the Goddess... tell you our chances?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: She didn’t need to. I know we can do this, Teb.

Speaker: Teb
Text: Maybe we can. This place... It really couldn’t be more different to the Sacred Lands, could it?
[Aloy returns to Meridian.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Olin’s apartment. Feels... empty. Should I sleep? Did leave anything unfinished?
[She lays on the bed.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: How could you sleep. Elisabet, with a weight like this pressing on you? How did you, Rost, after you lost your family? ...Sylens? Are you there? Guess I shouldn’t ask ghosts for advice.
[She rests before the final battle. Soon a soldier wakes he up.]

Speaker: Carja Guard
Text: Ma’am. There are signs from the west Sun-King Avad awaits you at the Temple of the Sun.
[Aloy shakes her head and goes to the Temple.]

Speaker: Avad
Text: Campfires, perhaps? Massing forces for the long march to the city gates?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That’s not wood smoke.

Speaker: Avad
Text: Then what is it?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The end. Or how it begins, anyway.
[The watchtower explodes far from the city with such force that it destroys a part of the rock underneath it. Avad is shocked. An army of war machines marching to the city.]

Speaker: Avad
Text: The Deathbringers you spoke of?!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: To the guns! To the guns! NOW!

Speaker: Avad
Text: By the Sun, do as she says!

Speaker: Vanguard Regular
Text: Set and loaded!

Speaker: Vanguard Regular
Text: All of you - be ready to fire!

Speaker: Avad
Text: Will the guns hold them back?

Speaker: Aloy
Text: We’re about to find out.
[A wall beneath the Temple explodes. ]

Speaker: Avad
Text: Helis?!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: No, Rally the Vanguard and send reinforcements!

Speaker: Avad
Text: Aloy – no!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: We need those guns!

Speaker: Avad
Text: He will cut you down!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Not this time.
[She jumps down to Helis and his heavily armed men.]

Speaker: Helis
Text: You have vexed me long enough.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Should have fought me in the Sun-Ring, then.
[The brutal bloodbath begins.]

Speaker: Helis
Text: Why do you fight? The end is inevitable.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Bridge can’t take much more of this!
[She’s inflicting enough wounds on Helis to get him to his knees.]

Speaker: Helis
Text: Impossible. I am chosen. This was not meant to be!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: You’re done. Hades is next.

Speaker: Helis
Text: The Buried Shadow will save me! I cannot--
[Aloy pierces him with her lance. Having cleared his pockets, she goes down to the Ridge.]

Speaker: Heavy Oseram Vanguard
Text: For Meridian! Hold the line!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Where do you need me?

Speaker: Heavy Oseram Vanguard
Text: Take up a cannon! On the platforms!
[A huge number of powerful machines are coming. Aloy begins to fire at them with a rocket launcher.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Here it comes! Better move!

Speaker: Heavy Oseram Vanguard
Text: Machines from the west!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Gotta get to another platform--

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Let’s do this.

Speaker: Heavy Oseram Vanguard
Text: Deathbringer fire incoming! Take cover from the Deathbringer! Look to the west!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Incoming! Gotta drop it and move!

Speaker: Heavy Oseram Vanguard
Text: No signs! A lull in the attack! Lower your arms! But be wary!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Chance to catch a breath--and prepare.

Speaker: Heavy Oseram Vanguard
Text: Raise arms again! West!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Well, they’re still surprised.

Speaker: Heavy Oseram Vanguard
Text: Beware, Nora! Incoming!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: It’s off! It’s taking a shot at me!

Speaker: Heavy Oseram Vanguard
Text: From the sky! Nora girl! Look out! By the Sun! All shadows descend on us!

Speaker: Heavy Oseram Vanguard
Text: It’s faring on your platform!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Don’t want to be here when that hits!

Speaker: Heavy Oseram Vanguard
Text: Stormbird! Stormbird! It fires on you, Nora!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Now it’s mad. Time to go! Incoming!

[At the end of the battle, a giant Khopesh comes in and shoots missiles at the city. Aloy throws away and she loses consciousness. When she wakes up, she sees that Meridian burns with hellish flames. Everything around her is destroyed. There are fierce fights with machines on the streets.]

Speaker: Teb
Text: Aloy! Aloy! Aloy!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Teb...?

Speaker: Teb
Text: Bu All-Mother, you survived! I thought you were killed.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: The others are they--?

Speaker: Teb
Text: No, no -- wounded, but alive, mostly!

Speaker: Teb
Text: The machines blasted through then kept going! They marched on the Spire, dragging that… thing with them.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Take care of the others, Teb. I’ve… got to go.
[She walks through a burning city, barely moving her legs.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Oh, no... Got to press on--

Speaker: Uthid
Text: Aloy, go! We’ll draw them! Now you face the true Sun, shadow demons!

Speaker: Aluki
Text: No Banuk... turns away... from a challenge.
[She dies.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Rest now, ice hunter. It’s begun! HADES is transmitting!
[The War Machines are begun to come out of the ground.]

Speaker: Graphic
Text: ACTIVATION SIGNAL - BIOMASS CONVERSION INITIATED

Speaker: Aloy
Text: If HADES has started the signal-- it must have gotten through the defenses! The Nora... Erend’s Vanguard... I have to get up there. Get to keep going. Keep pushing. Knew this wouldn’t be... easy. So no holding back. They’re alive!

Speaker: Erend
Text: Aloy! It’s Aloy! Well-- you can see that.

Speaker: Varl
Text: We thought you’d fallen at the ridge!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: No, the ridge fell on me. There isn’t a lot of time left. I have to face HADES.

Speaker: Varl
Text: Not alone.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: My fight. I can’t ask you to come with me.

Speaker: Erend
Text: We were about to go over the top anyway. Right?

Speaker: Varl
Text: Right

Speaker: Sona
Text: The Metal Devil must fall.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I should stock up. Last chance.
[She climbs to the top.]

Speaker: HADES
Text: Arrival of Entity... has been anticipated. Entity... will not halt transmission To contrary calculations are precise. Presence of Entity has been accounted for.
[It corrupts a Deathbringer that turns it into the biggest and the meanest of the war machines. Pure hatred in the metal form.]

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m gonna tie one down!

Speaker: Erend
Text: Understood! I’ll keep my hands off it.

Speaker: Sona
Text: The corrupted strike again! Be mindful!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: All of you, focus on the new machines! We’ve got time. Okay. Still got time.

Speaker: Varl
Text: We put down the last corrupted! It’s brought more of the corrupted, Aloy!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Take them out first!

Speaker: HADES
Text: Prioritize Entity.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Taking notice of me, huh? Help me bring it down!

Speaker: Varl
Text: We’ll get it off you!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: This one’s persistent!

Speaker: Varl
Text: Everyone, quickly!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Time enough to beat the machines back...

Speaker: Erend
Text: Scrapped ’em!

Speaker: Aloy
Text: That’s it-- my way’s clear!

Speaker: Varl
Text: The Deathbringer falls! The battle is ours!

Speaker: HADES
Text: System threat—imminent.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: I’m more than a threat.
[She purges HADES by stickin’ her freakin’ lance in his robotic eye.]

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Master Override, armed. To activate, state name and rank.

Speaker: Aloy
Text: Elisabet Sobeck... Alpha Prime.

Speaker: Synthetic Voice
Text: Master Override, activated. Purging Extinction Protocol.

[All War Machines disables. Seeing this, Avad smiles and hugs soaked in blood and sweat soldier. Everybody’s rejoicing. Aloy goes looking for Elisabet Sobeсk’s corpse, listening to the tape decoded by her Focus - GAIA Log: 3 Feb 2065 R]

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: Okay, GAIA. Sorry about that. Where was I?

Speaker: GAIA
Text: You were telling a story.

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: Right. Yeah… so, like I was saying, it was a children’s electronics kit, but I’d hacked the wiring to an auto battery and solar PV, so the grass caught fire. And so did a tall pine that’d stood there, I don’t know, maybe a hundred years.

Speaker: GAIA
Text: Query: you were how old?

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: Six. My mother was home, thank god, so she called the fire department and after, she took me out on the lawn and showed me the dead baby birds. Because there were nests in the pine tree.

Speaker: GAIA
Text: Query: What did you feel?

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: I’m not sure. I remember yelling that I didn’t care. And that’s when my mother took my face in her hands and... spoke.

Speaker: GAIA
Text: Query: What did she say?

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: She said I had to care. She said, “Elisabet, being smart will count for nothing if you don’t make the world better. You have to use your smarts to count for something, to serve life, not death.”
[She finds the corpse among the wreckage and picks up some necklace, thinking it belonged to Elisabet.]

Speaker: GAIA
Text: You often tell stories of your mother. But you are childless.

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: I never had time. I guess it was for the best.

Speaker: GAIA
Text: If you had had a child, Elisabet, what would you have wished for him or her?

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: I guess... I would have wanted her to be… curious. And willful - unstoppable, even… but with enough compassion to heal the world… just a little bit. Anyway that’s all live got for now, GAIA. Time to tuck in.

Speaker: GAIA
Text: I wish you a pleasant sleep, Elisabet.

Speaker: Elisabet Sobeck
Text: Thank you. I’ll catch you tomorrow.
[CREDITS]
[After the credits, we have a little scene ahead of us. The red energy clot comes out of the de-energized HADES. Sylens catches this clot with some kind of lantern.]

Speaker: Sylens
Text: Hello old friend. Remember me? We’ve still so much to discuss, so much you never revealed. Your Masters, for example. The ones who sent the signal that woke you. Knowledge has its rewards, don’t you think? Well... let’s begin.
[He walks towards the Grave-Hoard. The screen fades.]
